Two things:1. It's a very depressing read. So if you are depressed, or are in the process of dumping it, please postpone the read to when you know you've overcome it.2. Find your Midori. Then don't let her go.

When I was young, I loved Judy Blume books - Are You There God, It's Me Margaret?, Deenie, Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing, Blubber, and so on. Later, as a sixth-grader, I was in a bookstore and saw a book she wrote that I'd heard absolutely nothing about. I didn't even know it existed. Assuming it was another glorious, innocent, kid-friendly tale that I would love, I excitedly handed it to my mom to purchase for me, and in her equal lack of knowledge about its contents, I became the proud owner of ... Forever. For any of you who ever read that book, let me assure you it was NOT kid-friendly, and was rather a literary and occasionally graphic crash course in a girl losing her virginity with her first love. Needless to say I was shocked by what I was reading, but then pretty much showed all the dog-eared "dirty" parts to all my friends at school, as we giggled amongst ourselves. It still had her charm as an author - I was just a little young to be reading it.Why do I bring this up? Here's why. Sometimes you pick a book blindly, knowing nothing of the storyline, and solely basing your decision on the goodwill you have towards the author or their reputation. I'd heard of Haruki Murakami but had never read any of his works and this book happened to be an available e-book at my library. Unlike my shockingly revelatory, but overall positive experience with Blume's Forever, I walk away from this one feeling just ... dirty. I truly wish this hadn't been my first experience with reading his works because, honestly, it makes me want to steer clear of his other books. It's a pity, because starting the book I was immediately drawn in by his often poetically beautiful use of language. I can see that he's a skilled writer, is adept at creating a mood, and given other subject matter, I'd imagine I might even enjoy other works of his. In the end, this story would have been elevated so much by just developing the character personalities and emotional foundations for their relationships.The story is told in the first person narrative of a young man named Toru, who during the course of the book is torn between his love for the tragically flawed Naoko, and the highly spirited, often obnoxious Midori. Toss into the stew the kind, but also deeply flawed Reiko, Toru's narcissistic friend Nagasawa, and a host of other less visible, but also damaged characters and you get: he's a mess, they're a mess, everyone's a messy mess. There's not one truly likeable major character in the book, and by the end, which in theory should have been a happy one, I just wanted the whole ride to be over. Unfortunately, with this love story, it just felt like Murakami was finding excuses to write semi-frequent, highly descriptive, anatomically detailed, non-sensical to the plot, spin the roulette wheel to find your partner, depictions of sex. Toru’s “manhood” in this book gets so much attention it could be its own character, and, apparently, it’s irresistible to the women around him, despite his hum-drum personality. The worst of the gratuitous stuff is Reiko's backstory with her sociopathically precocious young piano student, which I'll spare you the gory details of, other than to say there's no good reason for that to exist in literature. For those still interested in the book after my less-than-glowing review, I want to offer a trigger warning that themes of loneliness, depression, suicide, mental illness, parental death, and unfulfilled love permeate the pages, so if you’re sensitive to those topics, avoid this book. I know the book is highly rated, but it’s just not for me. ★★ 1/2

“Norwegian Wood” used to be my favourite book when I first read it but after rereading I just couldn’t connect with the writing style and ended up hating it. I so badly want to fall back in love with this book, so I’m definitely planning on reading it for a third time and hopefully loving it just as much as I did the first time I read it. Still, nothing compares to the melancholic and nostalgic atmosphere in this book - like a rainy day in book form. I love Naoko so much

**2.5 stars**“What happens when people open their hearts?""They get better.”
They say, you either hate Murakami, or you fawn over his writings. But for me, he always comes in the middle. That is, I don’t fawn over him, though each of his books that I’ve read is an unforgettable experience which I wish I could say held for every other of my favourite authors. Hell, even Stephen King has unloaded his pile of trash in some of his works though I feel that’s not unlikely given the massive number of books he has written. (Well, none of them is practically forgettable, but very few became hazy for me. Not that it means he will ever cease to be my one of all-time favourites, though).Saying which, this one is the lightest read that I’ve had this year. Of course, it’s emotionally challenging, obviously, it is thought-provoking and all that elements that are needed to make a deserving bestseller, but I managed to read almost the whole in two sittings, so you know, you just flow through the pages. Without a doubt, the credit goes to Jay Rubin. But the writing isn’t something that can blow your mind like it’s definitely lucid and minimalistic, but apart from that, I can definitely say Murakami’s writing has become waaaay better over the years.The best part about the story is the pop culture references, and also because Toru Watanabe is literally a precocious nerd, his whole narrative has a kind of weird relevance and I think that holds for me. The gloomy atmosphere that he manages to establish from the very first page, is nothing short of addictive, despite being a bit stereotypical for all those reluctant introverts who sort of behave like nothing can leave a very hard-hitting impression on them. But here there is an exception, though. And I love the way Murakami deals with the concept of life and death in a semi-abstract way that is magical at the same time as being grounded. And how a single death can leave so deep and profound an impression on the mind of even the most emotionally detached fellow in the world, is spectacularly dealt with in the novel. And from both perspectives, one of breaking for it, and the other of healing from it.Also, as I mentioned, Watanabe is a nerdy guy. And that certainly has its good sides, and his taste in literature and music is quite applaudable. Kind of reminds me of Charlie from Perks of Being a Wallflower, despite Charlie being one of the most innocent literary characters I’ve ever come across. Cerebral disorders, complete psychological breakdowns and emotional turmoil are also treated outstandingly throughout the novel. Especially through Naoko and Reiko’s characters. And the importance of decision-making and all the ways a simple support can provide a psychological backbone for a person, in all the ways a simple promise of ‘I will wait for you’ can matter. However, it’s great that despite trying to leave you on a kind of cliffhanger, Murakami was just as successful as Wong Kar-Wai in Chungking Express. Well, because for the majority of the pages, the story is just morbidly depressing.
“But who can say what's best? That's why you need to grab whatever chance you have of happiness where you find it, and not worry about other people too much. My experience tells me that we get no more than two or three such chances in a lifetime, and if we let them go, we regret it for the rest of our lives.”
Now coming to the bad part. Murakami couldn’t handle sexuality in this novel. I have seen that in his other works, but in most of the case the subject matter is so heavy that it won’t concern you, but the fact remains (Norwegian Wood being his most popular novel and if a person has read only one book by Murakami then it’s this one) Murakami can’t write female characters. It’s one of the prime reasons why the storytelling got so irritating at parts. (Now, I won’t be talking spoilers but if you don’t want to know any part of the story it’s best to skip this paragraph, but I hope you don’t) First of all, say a girl wears a very short skirt. Now it is not a big problem if the protagonist thinks it’s too revealing, probably the author wants the protagonist to be shown in the hypocritically sexist and conservative light. Also, people will stare at her in general, because most of the men are being raised up that way. I’m sad to say but that’s true, at least from in India that holds. (My girlfriend actually feels uncomfortable nowadays if she wears something that, say reveals a bit of her stomach but isn’t a saree, the city is crowded with assholes comfortable with eve-teasing. But let’s not get off the topic, it’s a review, not my personal blog) But when a writer is deliberately making one of her female characters wear a dress like that, and everyone from her friends to her boyfriend to even the doctors in the hospital objectifies her and she seems to find that okay, I am pretty doubtful of what Murakami actually wanted to tell. If all that was from a feminist pov, at least in one instance someone should’ve pointed out to the rest of the ‘guys’ that she can actually wear whatever she feels like. Or maybe the entire thing should’ve been done in a matter-of-fact tone so as to leave the justification up to the readers. And it goes on and on. And okay, I get it that sex is really an integral part of our lives and so it isn’t abnormal to think about that once someone who was once your partner dies. But you’re only thinking about that fellatio? When the girl has left all other kinds of impressions in you from her entire lifetime, dude I seriously doubt you will think about that only. Maybe, I mean maybe you actually didn’t love her at all like you claimed to do?  For sex is really an important part of a majority of relationships, and definitely one of the building blocks and perhaps even the holding pillar (Non-generalized, of course). But it 
isn’t
 the relationship. And that’s just one character, I mean. I haven’t even started on the abominable philosophies of one of the characters who justifies sleeping with a different girl every day despite having a girlfriend as ’men’s having sexual hunger that is incomprehensible for any woman’. But if you choose to ignore all of that, it’s certainly a story that will stay with you. It’s a bit like watching Christopher Nolan’s movies: everything’s good, except no developed female characters. But that’s better though, at least when you don’t know how to do something, you shouldn’t do it. Basically, I forgot to add this one to Goodreads at first. And then after finishing, I had this weird urge to rate it 1 star just because of the reasons I have stated, but then decided against it. I’m still kinda unsure of the rating and may remove it soon if I can’t make sure of whether the pros. outweigh the cons.To be honest, it’s still all-around confusion for me. Am I missing something here? Why the hell does so many people love it when I have so many problems with it? It has its good parts like the importance of mental health and everything, and for those I like it, but I can never even come close to saying it's adorable in any way. And I will not recommend it to you if you, like me, can close your eyes to all those flaws.
“Don't feel sorry for yourself. Only assholes do that.”

I have to make it clear: I'm a fan of Haruki Murakami's novels, who is not able to give his books anything less than three stars.I first read Norwegian Wood when I was 13 years old and at that time I understandably failed to get what all the fuss is about. I even thought "A lot of sex and nothing is solved in the end, I'm bored out of my mind. What's the point...?" Therefore I understand why a lot of people don't like Norwegian Wood and think it's just a book about a hapless young man getting laid.But years later I re-read the book, then re-read it once again in English. Slowly I managed to see what Mr. Murakami tries to express in this best selling novel of his. Norwegian Wood, by Murakami's own words, is a "100% love story. A sad, quiet, strong love story". The plot is a simple and overused enough one: Boy loves girl, girl loves his best friend; best friend commits suicide, girl goes mad, boy tries to move on; boy meets another girl, and now boy is caught between his two different love interests, unable to come up with a solution. There are many books with similar themes and Norwegian Wood clearly isn't the best among its kind (Natsume Sōseki's memorable novel 
And Then
 comes to mind). But Mr. Murakami had managed to express much, much more than just relationship and romance in this book. Instead of a typical romance, Mr. Marakami wrote about coming of age, sex, death and madness, the confusion and boredom of youth, the slow pain of people and things you hold dear slipping through your grip, and the struggle to search for meaning when everything seems more or less pointless. He also wrote about a man stood between the quiet, peaceful realm of death and memories and the imperfect land of the living, unable to decide where to go. It's an easy book to read, it also has a good sense of humor and a handful of comical moments, the supporting characters are vivid and lively; once you get on with the story, you may find yourself unable to stop following the main character through his journey of soul searching.This book is narrated in first person by the male Main Character named Toru Watanabe. When Toru started tells the story about his past, he's already a 38 years old adult, but I found how he narrated his lost days of youth with so much longing and regret that I cannot help but be captured by his story.To be honest, Toru isn't always a likable character, he can be selfish, withdrawn and aloof at times; but since I can understand him and his feeling therefore I'm fine with him. I can always relate to Toru as a loner who wanted to reach out and be loved but couldn't do it well. For most of the time I like seeing things and people through his eyes. Toru's two love interests and the other supporting characters are impressive in their own different ways as well.Norwegian Wood does have its share of flaws (I really don't like how Toru talks about the student movements in 1970s, and his interaction with women can be icky at times), and I don't think it is Mr. Murakami best works but it clearly is a highly emotional, melodic coming of age novel.

I'm not sure what exactly I'm supposed to get out of this book apart from gross descriptions of sex(my actual reaction to most of this book)  
As far as I can tell, this book is about:
- 
Toru not being able to keep it in his damn pants.
 When Midori tells him she wants to lie down with him, he tells her, "If I go to bed with a girl, I'm going to want to do it with her, and I sure as hell don't want to lie there struggling to restrain myself. I'm not kidding, I might end up forcing you." You expect me to sympathize with Toru when he says shit like this? THERE ISN'T A SINGLE FEMALE CHARACTER IN THIS BOOK WHO DOESN'T HAVE SEX WITH TORU. Also, if I have to hear about how big Toru's penis is one more time I'm going to lose it.- Toru wallowing in his Manpain because he can't have sex with the girl he wants - Toru getting wasted all the time- Midori being oh-so-Quirky and Edgy (not to mention REALLY FREAKING PETTY)- Naoko having no personality apart from the fact that she's a) Toru's love interest and b) mentally illYeah...this book was not to my taste, to say the least.

I cannot stop thinking about this book. It is very sad. The writing is beautiful, poetic and full of emotion. I read a couple of reviews that said this isn't a love story but it felt like a love story to me. A heartbreaking love story. There are many references to The Beatles music and it made me want to listen to their music which I have been doing all week. 5 stars for the emotional, beautiful writing."In the deepening spring of May, I had no choice but to recognize the trembling of my heart. It usually happened as the sun was going down. In the pale evening gloom, when the soft fragrance of magnolias hung in the air, my heart would swell without warning, and tremble, an lurch with a stab of pain. I would try clamping my eyes shut and gritting my teach, and wait for it to pass. And it would pass - but slowly, taking its time, and leaving a dull ache behind."A very sad book but I could not stop turning the pages. This book may not be for everyone though, mental illness and suicide are a big part of this story.

Con questo romanzo del 1987 Haruki Murakami affronta il tema dell'adolescenza come epoca di passaggio tra la spensieratezza dell'infanzia e la responsabilità dell'età adulta: protagonista il giovane Wakanabe, serio e riflessivo, e i suoi rapporti con gli amici Kizuki e Nagasawa e con le giovani donne Naoko e Midori che in modo diverso ma altrettanto impegnativo lo attraggono profondamente.Senza entrare in merito alla trama preferisco porre l'accento sulla bravura dell'autore di affrontare e raccontare con delicata determinazione, grazie ad una prosa tanto semplice e scorrevole quanto poetica, tematiche difficili e intime proprie dell'adolescenza, i contrasti e le diverse filosofie di vita dei giovani quando, allontanatisi dalla famiglia, affrontano il complicato labirinto emotivo esistenziale verso l'età adulta, non sempre risolvendolo in maniera propositiva.Un romanzo che si legge d'un fiato e, a libro concluso, mi ha regalato un pizzico di malinconia retrospettiva, ripensando alla mia adolescenza perduta, agli anni formativi che mi hanno condotto a quello che sono adesso.
رواية كئيبة ومملة .. كثرة في التفاصيل مع ندرة في الأحداث .. حوار رتيب وساذج وأفكار سطحية هشة .. بالإضافة إلى سوء الترجمة ...
KIMI DA YO KIMI NANDA YOOOOO, OSHIETE KURETAAAAA tak na serio to im dalej tym lepiej.

I finished the book over an hour ago. I read the last sentence, took a deep breath, kept the book aside and then went to bed and slept. I knew I needed time to clear my head, needed time before I came and here typed out meaningless rambles.This is a story that felt personal for me, I was addicted to it reading nonstop at a stretch unable to put it down but at the same time so painful. As I told my friend 'it was as if I was watching a friend struggling in a toxic realtionship but I cannot advice him so as to save my friendship with him'. Which ultimately meant for me, that the relationship I had with the said friend, is not a healthy one either, or maybe it just meant we are not close enough and not in a place to fully understand each other. Anyone with a sound mind could see that Naoki's and Reika's connection to Toru was simply unhealthy. Maybe I was in the minority with my thoughts with that. This is one of those rare reviews that I am writing before reading other reviews. I came here straight to write my thoughts down as soon as I woke up. Maybe it's sleep-filled brain just spouting nonsense too. Later when I look back on this and think it's too cringey, I am just going to use that excuse. As I was saying, for me their relationships with each other mirrored something from the past just as Toru thought that his, Hatsumi's and Nagisawa's mirrored his, Naoko's and Kizuki'z. It felt like a cycle. In a way it was. In the end it was as if Midori was that only outside factor. The only thing holding Toru grounded. Maybe it's the small romantic in me saying that, but in the whole book, the only character I felt any likeness was to Midori, the only character I could even stand.For me this was not a 'love story' but a deep meaning to look into what it was to be alive. Toru continued on, he never thought of ending his life, even when everyone around him seem to be leaving. At a glance we can imagine that even Reika might end her life but then we have Midori. That strong pull, the girl who endures it all and she manages to stay alive. Maybe inadvertently, this managed to keep Toru alive. It took him time to sought out his feelings but he did. As a reader we are left with the question, did Midori and Toru work out in the end? But one thing was sure. He was able to leave the memory of Naoko behind. She had become a fading memory as she should. Does this make me cold-hearted? But I am one to believe that when people die, they die. Yes they will leave us with memories but as the living, we are not supposed to hang on to those memories and squander off our lives based on it. I have always told my family that if I ever die, don't erect tombstone for me. Don't go each year to the cemetery and lament about my death. I am gone. Be happy for the years I lived cuz I believe that I've led them to the fullest.I do not want to finish this in such a melancholic note but then again this whole story is filled with that. Everything seems just sad to me. There were plenty of times I felt as if my life was mirrored with Toru and sometimes with Midori (maybe that is the reason she is my favorite character in the story) thus making the story even more impactful on me. This is my first Murakami book and as I speak there are four more on my shelves collecting dust. Surprisingly I read this one the moment I bought it. Will I dive straight into the rest? Maybe. I've heard that Norwegian Woods is a change in genre to his books and one which does not use magical realism as his others. I do want to read a book which contains his forte in it but I think I will leave it for a while. Before I end I want to write a few words about the beautiful yet simple writing style. It goes hand in hand with what I've ehard about the author himself. There is something so charming in that. Soothing even. In the end this is what draws me back to his work. Till I find time and motivation to read another of his (it might be in another week, year or even just today itself) I will say adios for this review.

Tôi thường xuyên bị rơi vào hoàn cảnh ú a ú ớ khi người khác hỏi về những chi tiết trong 1 cuốn sách nào đó mà họ biết rằng tôi đã đọc. Chẳng mấy khi tôi nhớ một cách rõ ràng nội dung, tình tiết câu chuyện, đến cả tên nhân vật đôi khi còn lẫn lộn lung văn tung :)) Thứ tôi nhớ rõ ràng nhất, sắc nét nhất chỉ là cảm giác - cảm giác khi đọc nó.Cảm giác là một vấn đề thuộc phạm trù tình cảm. Bình sinh tôi là người mê những câu chuyện khiến mình cảm giác day dứt, mông lung, mơ hồ, u ám, tăm tối, thậm chí muốn đập đầu vào tường :)) Vậy mà tôi lại chết mê chết mệt Midori - cô gái mà tôi đã từng viết ở đâu đó là làm sáng bừng lên cả câu chuyện. Modori đem lại một sự vui tươi, thoải mái và dễ chịu cực kỳ.Mỗi đoạn xuất hiện Midori, câu chuyện lại rực rỡ sao sao ấy cho dù đó là lúc cô say rượu tới mức đi toilet ngủ quên trong đó hay to mồm muốn leo lên những cái cây cổ thụ cao thật là cao để tè lên đầu toàn thể nhân loại, há há :))Trong khi Naoko tạo cho tôi một cảm giác không có thật, mờ mờ như sương, nhạt nhòa thiếu sức sống thì Midori "của tôi" lại như một thái cực hoàn toàn trái ngược. Cô gái ấy rất thật rất đời, luôn muốn được để ý và quan tâm, ngay thẳng, mãnh liệt, yêu sự tự do, dám yêu, dám ghét, dám khẳng định bản thân, không bao giờ trốn tránh...Chẹp, hôm qua có một đứa bất chợt mò vào thư viện chỗ nó và nhìn thấy "Rừng Na Uy". Ngay lập tức nó mượn về và inbox cho tôi bảo nó nghĩ tới tôi khi nhìn thấy cuốn sách. Há, thật là 1 sự vinh dự nào đó. Nó lại còn có vẻ rất hâm mộ Kiko - diễn viễn đóng vai Midori trong phim của đạo diễn Trần Anh Hùng. Nói về phim thì tôi không thực sự thích lắm. Liệu có phải Midori của đạo diễn quá khác Midori của tôi. Tôi cũng chẳng biết Midori của tôi như thế nào nữa vì đó đơn thuần là vẫn đề cảm giác, như đã nói. Tôi đang tìm kiếm thứ cảm giác đó ngoài cuộc đời thật những vẫn chưa tìm ra. Hê, hy vọng sẽ sớm tìm được ra."Vì là của chú rồi nên cháu đọc cũng chẳng thành của cháu được", đứa ấy đã nói thế, hồn nhiên ghê :))

خواندن اين كتاب، بعد از مطالعه "جنس دوم" سيمون دوبوار، آدم را در جايگاه قاضى سختگيرى مى نشاند كه در نهايت حكم به اشد مجازات خواهد داد.همه مى گويند اين كتاب "روايت نبرد آدم هاى معمولى شهر است." اما من مى گويم اين كتاب "روايت نبرد "مرد"هاى معمولى شهر است." اگر كمى حساس باشيد، كاملا متوجه مى شويد كه زن ها، در اين كتاب جنس دوم هستند. بيشتر چيزهايى كه درباره زن هاى كتاب مى دانيم، چهره هايشان است. زن هاى جوان عمدتا دمدمى مزاج و عصبى و ضعيف هستند! حتى اگر با مشكلات بسيارى دست و پنجه نرم كرده باشند، باز هم به شكلى به تصوير كشيده شده اند كه گويى بدون حمايت يك مرد، ضعيف و ناقصند. درباره مردها بيش از آنكه چهره و ظاهرشان توصيف شود، شخصيتشان توصيف مى شود و بواسطه شخصيتشان جذاب هستند، درست برخلاف زن ها! داستان به شدت پر از كليشه هاى جنسيتى است، مدام با جمله هايى مواجه مى شويم كه صفاتى خاص را به همه دخترها نسبت مى دهد. مثلا در جايى از كتاب مى خوانيم: "دخترهاى معمولى جوانى كه همسن من هستند، اساسا منصفانه بودن يا نبودن چيزها برايشان بى اهميت است." قضاوتى كلى و به نظر من بى معنى درباره همه دخترها! چنين قضاوت هايى را درباره مردها در كتاب نمى بينيم. حتى نحوه پايان كتاب هم به گونه اى است كه به طرز پررنگى جنس دوم بودن زنان را نشان مى دهد! نمى توانم بگويم كه با خواندنش لذت نخواهيد برد! داستان هاى عاشقانه فى نفسه جذابند، وقتى با قلم موراكامى نوشته شوند، جذاب تَر هم مى شوند، ولى اين كتاب را با آگاهى از كليشه هاى جنسيتى اش بخوانيد! با آگاهى از اينكه "آنچه بايد باشد"، لزوما اين چيزى نيست كه در كتاب به تصوير كشيده شده.

اولین رمانی که از موراکامی خوندم.شیوه نوشتن ساده و جزئی موراکامی رو خیلی دوست داشتم. از این رمان، بیشتر از مجموعه داستان‌هاش خوشم اومد. به دلیل اینکه فضاسازی خوبی داشت و ماجرا خوب جلو می‌رفت و با اینکه توصیفات نسبتن زیادی داشت، اما خسته‌کننده نبود. توصیفات طوری بود که می‌تونستی تصور‌شون کنی و توصیفات اضافی‌ای نبودن و باعث فضاسازی حسی بهتر می‌شدن و برای همین از خوندنش خسته نمی‌شدی و می‌تونستی حجم زیادی که داره رو با کنجکاوی بخونی و بری جلو.ترغیب شدم که حتمن باقی رمان‌هاش رو هم بخونم و ازشون غافل نشم به دلیل تاثیر حسی خوبی که داشت.اگر خیلی‌خیلی روی اسپویل حساسید، بقیه متن رو نخونید.***اما پایان بهتری برای انتظار داشتم. در واقع پایانی که این رمان داشت، شخصیت رو توی منگنه قرار نمی‌داد و شخصیت دست به انتخاب نمی‌زد، در صورتی که داستان، شرایطی برای شخصیت به‌وجود اورده بود که مجبور بود دست به انتخاب مهمی بزنه، اما انگار خود نویسنده هم نتونسته بود از پس انتخاب بر بیاد و به صورت مبتدیانه‌ای کتاب رو تموم کرد و صورت مساله رو پاک کرد.

This book was so disgusting. Toru as the main character is so so so mediocre. All the women are horrible and flat; they literally just exist to satisfy Toru's sexual desires and fantasies. He literally has sex with 3/4 of the significant female characters, and he's "so good at sex" that two swear they'll never have sex again. How many ways can I reiterate that this is SO MISOGYNIST. Why were there so many dry, uncomfortable, unromantic sex scenes? Why was there that one with a 13 year old?? So gross and unnecessary (even if it may or may not have actually happened). Murakami is WAY better when he's doing magical realism, when the grotesque sex fits into the aesthetic. Instead this was just creepy and anti-women. Big NOPE for me!! Mediocre "nice guys" stop thinking all women exist to give sexual favors challenge.

En el 2008, yo aún trabajaba en la Casa de la Cultura de Nuevo León, apoyaba como auxiliar de la Biblioteca, había comenzado a escuchar toneladas de música, guiado e influenciado por el buen Gildardo, iba al Garage en el Barrio Antiguo de Monterrey, y estaba a punto de separarme de mi pareja en la que fuera mi segunda relación más larga hasta ese momento.En ese contexto leí Sputnik, mi amor, la primera novela de Murakami a la que me había acercado. No recuerdo que me dijera gran cosa, me queda el halo de una prosa que sentí fría, distante, casi podría decir aséptica y una atmósfera clínica.Recuerdo que mi tocayo y sensei, el Arturo, me preguntó si tenía la de Tokio Blues Norwegian Wood, del Murakami; y sí, se la terminé prestando. En una tocada de quién sabe qué grupo, en el Garage, me la devovió. Ni idea si le gustó o no. Hace qué, 11, 12 años de eso.-Hoy, reacomodando libros por todo el departamento, le platicaba a la Lizbeth sobre mi interés en saber qué libros dejaba más a la vista, porque yo tengo esa costumbre de husmear los libreros y estanterías de las casas que visito, me dan una idea de lo que le interesa o puede interesar a las personas que habitan ese espacio; alimento mis prejuicios leyendo los lomos de los libros que guardan conocidos y extraños.La mañana del domingo 12 de julio, de entre todos los libros que tiene Lizbeth en su librero, el que más llamó mi atención fue este; así que lo tomé, agarré mi taza de café de olla cargadísimo, me senté en el piso del comedor, y mientras esperaba que ella terminara una videollamada con sus amigas en distintas ciudades del mundo: me puse a leer.Desde las primeras páginas me atrapó, y me intrigaba más saber si le había gustado a su dueña, o qué opinaba de este libro, o cómo había llegado a sus manos.Seguí leyendo un poco más y dejaba que el sol que entraba por la puerta doble de cristal que daba a un pequeño balcón me calentara un poco. Levantaba la vista y me permitía que la trama de Watanabe se fuera colando con mis pensamientos de esa mañana.Una vez que terminó su llamada y mientras almorzabamos me contó que a ella no le había gustado el libro, y eso fue el detonante para que me interesara leerlo, jaja. Además, se ofreció a prestármelo, aunque yo estaba seguro que sí tenía mi copia en mi departamento, cosa que no es así. También, insistió un poco, “este fue el libro que me acompañó en mi viaje de hace unos años por Europa”. El libro se veía un poco maltratado y con una pequeña mancha de café en las primeras hojas, todo eso, y la mirada y la sonrisa de ella eran lo único que necesitaba para desear leerlo. Así que lo acepté y me lo llevé.-Watanabe narra la novela desde sus 37 años, recordando sus años de universidad, la muerte por suicidio de su mejor y único amigo, Kizuki, y lo que sucedería tiempo después, con otras personas a las que se volvería cercano: Naoko, ex novia de Kizuki, Midori, una compañera de su carrera, y Reiko, una especie de doctora/enfermera/sanadora espiritual.La novela te atrapa, al menos a mí, demasiadas referencias literarias y musicales, un trasunto de la novela es La montaña mágica, de Thomas Mann, (libro que servía de ¿base? a la lámpara en la mesita de noche de Lizbeth: ¿habrá leído ese libro por este otro? ¿Coincidencia?).De La montaña mágica recuerdo que me dijo mientras desayunábamos que tampoco le había gustado y que le había parecido aburridísimo, y recordaba haber platicado con el Arturo “hace poco” --voy buscando la conversación, y eso fue en julio de 2018, ¡¡julio de 2018!! Maldita memoria--: Hace poco me compré una edición de Edhasa de La Montaña Mágicahabía intentado leerla también como en 1998.Y no avanzaba de la página 40Me parecía un ladrillo insulso y mal contadoY ahora que intenté de nuevo PUM!Pinche novelón pendejo.Volví a percibir ese caracter distante del narrador que creo recordar de la otra novela,Distancia en el tiempo, en los narradores, en las conversaciones, en la memoria que es más poco confiable que nada, y por tanto más segura que todo dato comprobable.Toda la lectura de la novela estuvo acompañada de seguir conversando con Lizbeth y adentrarme en su mundo, en sus ideas, en su vida: “Creo que ya sé por qué no te gustó la novela, o la menos tengo algunas ideas”, le dije. “Por la aparente frialdad de sus personajes, por su tratamiento del sexo, de las relaciones interpersonales, por su tristeza profunda”, me aventuré en adivinar. Todavía es día que no platico con ella sobre el libro porque primero quería escribir este comentario sobre mi lectura. Primero quería aterrizar un poco mis ideas, yo, un poco como el narrador: “soy ese tipo de personas que no acaba de comprender las cosas hasta que las pone por escrito”.Me gusta el minimalismo de la novela, pocos personajes, un narrador que no parece cuestionarse gran cosa el mundo que lo rodea, pero que lo ve con unos ojos que siento que terminan por atravesarlo todo, por expresarse del mundo “hablando raro”, en palabras de los demás personajes, pero en el fondo, siento, siendo brutalmente honesto, sin filtros, abierto y transparente, estamos tan acostumbrados a las convenciones sociales, que cuando alguien, educadamente, no las sigue, nos parece extraño y ajeno.-Entre la carga de mi trabajo, estar absorto conociendo a la increíble mujer que es la Lizbeth, y tratar de ir al día con la lectura de La estación de la calle Perdido, de China Miéville, que debía leer durante ese mes de julio también para el grupo de lectura de ciencia-ficción al que estoy adscrito; Tokio Blues fue el único libro que pude terminar de leer.Me gustó, me gustó su trama y cómo se fue desarrollando, me gustó su acercamiento a las enfermedades mentales y en alternativas de tratamiento, me gustó que los personajes se aceptaran limitados, uhm, bueno, no así, quiero decir que los personajes de esta novela de Murakami son conscientes de sus limitaciones, de sus fronteras. Me gustó que me la prestara ella.Me da gusto no haberla leído antes, me da cierta alegría reconocer eso de “para cada tiempo hay un libro”, porque este llegó en un momento muy especial de mi vida, y de manos de alguien sumamente especial; no creo que lo hubiera leído igual antes o después; me gustan esas caprichosas coincidencias que depositan en mis manos novelas que, a pesar de que no me cambiarán la vida, me dirán mucho más por el resto del tiempo que las siga repensando.

"A gentleman is someone who does not do what he wants to do but what he should do," is advice that sounds good until you think about it for like one second. What the fuck does this gentleman want to do? It's one of the central questions in Norwegian Wood, which returns to the issue of consent again and again. People keep calling our narrator a nice guy, but..."The first girl put up a terrific struggle when I tried to get her undressed and into the hotel bed," he says. I feel like people are confused because he keeps telling them that he'd "like to have a nice, long talk" with them and they don't realize how Patrick Bateman that sounds. "If you feel like raping someone in the middle of the night," says his girlfriend's roommate later, "don't get the wrong one."Neither of those two feel reliable. The roommate - Reiko - tells this long story, right in the middle of the book, about how her 13-year-old student seduced her and then accused her of rape, and she's like "So my marriage and life were destroyed, because who would believe my side of the story?" and you're like, um, not me either?Those of you who have read this book already are like "It's not about consent! It's about suicide!" and okay, it is true that there are Shogun levels of suicide up in here, how is that island even still populated if everyone keeps offing themselves like this, good gosh. And what is Murakami trying to get at? Why does he keep returning to force, rape, consent and suicide? Listen to this story: "I don't know you well enough to force stuff on you," says Watanabe to his new girlfriend Midori - not Reiko's roommate, that's the plot, it's a love triangle between Watanabe and his mentally unstable girlfriend Naoko and his "well you were in an asylum, so..." other girlfriend Midori - anyway, and she's like "You mean if you knew me better, you'd force stuff on me like everybody else?" and he goes, "It's possible. That's how people live in the real world, forcing stuff on each other."And so, some of the characters in this book choose not to live in that real world. And are those the choices Murakami is presenting us with? Yikes. He comes off so pleasant, Murakami does, he writes these twee little conversations, but under all his infamous quirks...that's a deep well, man. It's dark down there. Murakami spends half of this book making Magic Mountain references and the other half with Euripides: "What marks his plays is the way things get so mixed up the characters are trapped," Watanabe posits, but "There's always a deus ex machina." And where is our deus now, gentlemen?

Book Review: Haruki Murakami, Norwegian Wood (Vintage, London, 2000)I have never been good at reading translations. It's always in the back of my mind that what I'm reading is not the piece in its original forms: it is not how the author originally wished it to be presented. I don't know, therefore, whether it is to Murakami or Norwegian Wood's translator Jay Rubin who I should give the credit for keeping me thoroughly engaged with this one.I immediately connected to Toru, the narrator and protagonist, because he was a university student, a reader, who was 19 and turning 20. Even though the character is in 1960s Japan, so much of the mundane aspects of his every day life were things that I could connect to.I found the exploration of 'normal' and 'not-normal' incredibly intriguing. Whilst Naoko and Reiko spend most of the novel in a sort of hospital, I never got the impression that they were any more strange than Toru (a self confessed loner), Midori (who has a strange fascination with pornography, and can't cry at her father's funeral), Nagasawa (who doesn't seem to have any real emotions or attachments) or Hatsumi (Nagasawa's long-suffering girlfriend, who comes off as very repressed). Where the difference lies, I think, is that Naoko and Reiko feel unhealthy through their lack of normality, and worry that the way they act, the way they think, hurts others as well as themselves.Suicide is an issue that runs throughout the novel, and with it (of course) does death. The messages coming through about these things were interesting. It seemed to me that Toru was unsure exactly what death meant to him, except for that 'Death exists, not as the opposite to, but as a part of life.' Looking back at the novel as a whole, I think death is handled in the same sort of way as in the Harry Potter series. (Odd comparison, I know) It has that same questioning nature, and the same raw honesty. It's something I have come to admire in authors when I feel this in their work.The novel is, more than anything, a coming of age novel about a love triangle. The two relationships work so well that I think as a reader you begin to feel a lot like Toru does: you want him to be with Naoko when she is in the scene, and you want him to be with Midori when she appears. It's not a traditional love triangle I suppose in that the girls do not compete for his heart. They both must just be themselves and see where they end up. It's not a story of epic love and passion, but it's subtle, and seems more real.The language in which Toru's world and feelings are described is simply gorgeous. I suppose I should credit both Murakami and Rubin here. I guess it's a collaborative effort, in many ways. So many simple sentences just reached out and grabbed me, either for their truth, beauty, wit or oddness.Overall, this is a fantastic novel that I would recommend to everyone who has experienced (or is still doing so) the rollercoaster ride that is growing up and living without anyone to hold your hand in the best way that you know how.(Not recommended at all for younger readers, some of the sex scenes and the language is quite graphic, as well as some themes being upsetting. I don't know if I could have read this when I was 16/17 for example, and really understood it.)

عزيزى موراكامىهذه آخر مغامرة لى مع رواياتك، يخالطنى شعور من الحزن والرضا فى آن واحد لإنتهائى من أعمالك .. والتى سأعاود قرائتها بالتأكيد ولن أمّل منها أبداً .الغابة النرويجية تأتى فى المكانة الثانية قربًا لقلبى بعد "كافكا على الشاطئ" اسم الرواية مقتبس من اسم أغنية لفرقة "البيتلز"، تقول ناروكو عن احساسها بالأغنية "هذه الأغنية تجعلني أشعر بحزن جارف. لا أعرف. يتراءى لي أنني أتجول في " غابةعميقة. وأنا وحدي في ظلمة باردة، لا أحد يأتي لإنقاذي." https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Ihn6..."توروتو واتنابي" يروِ لنا حكايته ، اعتمادًا على ذاكرته ال��عيدة حتى لا تتسرب ذكرى "ناروكو" من ذاكرته ، ويُبقِي على وعده لها باستمرار تذكرها. "أكثر شخصية أحببتها" بالمناسبة :')) ناروكو تلك الفتاة التى يلاحقها انتحار أحبائها بدءًا ��ن أختها، وانتهاءًا ب"كيزوكى" صديق طفولتها .. ناروكو التى لا تستطيع إيصال مشاعرها بالكلمات، فتصمت فقط وتختزل مشاعرها بداخلها ،ويزداد حزنها وانغلاقها على نفسها ونأيها عن الناس.تعانى من مشاكلها النفسية وحدها، و بإبعاد أحبائها عنها أيضاً.شخصيتها معقدة، يصعب الغور فى أسبارها .رايكو، ميدورى، هاتسومى، ناغاساوايبرع موراكامى فى التعمق فى شخصيات روايته بطريقة رائعة تجعل من الصعب عليك نسيانها، كل شخصية لها جمالها وأسلوبها الخاص. الفلسفة، الموسيقى، الكتب، والجنون هو ما ستكسبه من قرائاتك لموراكامىأتمنى أن يُتّرجم باقى أعماله، أو سأتعلم أنا اليابانية خصيصاً له :D

""زندگی خودتو بگیری؟ عبارت جالبیه، از کی بگیری؟وقتی که تموم بشه تو نیستی که از دستش می دی.مرگ تو چیزیه که برای بقیه اتفاق میافته، زندگی تو مال خودت نیست، ازش دست بکش""بعد از مدت ها کتابی رو خوندم که ترجیح می دم یه چند وقتی بگذره تا کتاب جدیدی رو دست بگیرم نه به خاطر بد بودن بلکه به خاطر تاثیر زیادی که داشت.موراکامی هیچ وقت نویسنده مورد علاقه من نبود، چرا که همیشه داستان های کوتاه اون رو خونده بودم و فضاسازی فانتزی داستان هاش رو دوست نداشتم، اما این کتاب دید من رو نسبت بهش تغییر داد.داستان روان و یک خطی جلو می رفت و حتی اتفاقات بد و خوب هم ساده نشون داده می شد، بی هیجان نبود اما شخصیت اصلی در ظاهر نسبت به اتفاقات دور و برش احساسی نشون نمی داد در حالی که درونش غوغا بود.شخصیت های دیگه هم خوب پرداخت شده بودند و حس و حالشون شبیه همه آدم های عادی بود.اینکه مرگ رو اینطوری اینقدر درگیر و درهم پیچیده در زندگی به این شیوه هنرمندانه و واقعی بیان کرده بود، ارتباط رو با کتاب و داستان و شخصیت ها بیشتر می کرد.تنها ایرادی که به داستان می تونم بگیرم اینه که برای جداسازی فضا فقط از غذا و نوشیدنی استفاده می شد، یک مقدار تو ذوق می زد.

I was thinking about giving this book 4 stars beacuse of some flaws. But I couldn't. Sorry everyone. It just left too much impact on my perception of the world. So, lets go with objective 4.5 stars, subjective 5. I really cannot believe that I loved this book so much. I don't really like Murakami's writing style, but in this book, it is how close it can be to perfection. This book is not just a book, it is a true gray reality about life and death, sorrow, happiness and loneliness. Full of emotion, it is at times a very depressive read, while at times madly joyful. Norwegian Wood really is a beautiful treasure that Murakami gave to the world, and I think that we should be grateful for that :)(I think I will cry while re-reading it)
“I didn't have much to say to anybody but kept to myself and my books. With my eyes closed, I would touch a familiar book and draw it's fragrance deep inside me. This was enough to make me happy.”

- التقيم : 2.5 ⭐

بدأت بكافكا على الشاطئ ثم 1Q84 ثم رقص رقص رقص واخيرا الغابة النروجية اللي طلعت عيني شهور طويلة 🙂رواية برائحة الحزن يكتبها موركامي، مخالفا لجميع رواياته التي عهدناها منه، رواية واقعية تخلوا من عوالم موركامي التى وقعت في حبها من أول لحظة السنة الماضية.

السؤال هنا : هل موركامي فشل في الروايات الواقعة؟= الإجابة : فشر طبعاً :')ولكننننن .. سبب تقيمي المنخفض هو أن أكثر من ٤٠ ٪ من الرواية عايزة اولع فيه، المشاهد الجنسية طاغية على الأحداث بطريقة بشعة!! ساعات كنت بحس أنها محور القصة وده شيء غير راقي بالمره ومنفر لأبعد حد!واجهتني صعوبة في الإندماج مع أجواء الرواية حتى المنتصف تقريبا، ربم�� بسبب اختلاف المترجم حسيت بأن فيه حاجة غلط حتى في الألفاظ اللي بتتقال 😒الرواية دي من أعلى الروايات لهاروكي من حيث الاقتباسات بالنسبالي، الرسائل بين تورو وتانابي وبقية الشخصيات دائما نالت اعجابي ولمست قلبي.

في المجمل، كانت تجربة نص نص والحمدلله أنها خلصت ع خير 😂-بلاي لست تضم الموسيقى التي ذُكرت في الرواية :Listen to Norwegian Wood music, a playlist by ڤالكث on #SoundCloudhttps://soundcloud.app.goo.gl/gvqWH

=الاقتباسات :أدركت أن الطريقة الوحيدة التي أستطيع بها الاستمرار في الحياة هي ان تشاركيني حياتي، وحين فقدتك استبد بي الألم والوحشة حقا.استمرت ناوکو : « لا أستطيع أبدا قول ما أريد قوله. يحصل معي دائما ما حصل قبل قليل . أحاول أن أقول شيئا، لكن ما أجده هو الكلمات الخطأ- الكلمات الخطأ ، أو الكلمات المناقضة تماما لما أقصده. أحاول تصحيح نفسي، غير أن الأمور تسوء أكثر. فأنشده عما كنت أحاول قوله لأبدأ به. وكأنني منشطرة إلى اثنتين ، ألعب الغميضة مع نفسي. يطارد النصف الأول النصف الآخر حول هذا البريد الكبير السمين. لدي ذاتي الأخرى الكلمات الصحيحة، لكن هذه الذات لا تستطيع لمسها ».هل تعد حق أنك لن تنساني أبدأ ؟ قلت : « لن أنساك أبدا ، ولن أستطيع أن أنساك أبدا ».لكن ذاكرتي تزداد سقوطأ في العتمة ، ولقد نسيت عددا من الأمور . حين أكتب من الذاكرة على هذا النحو ، أشعر غالبا بغصة الرهبة . ماذا لو كان ما نسيته أهم الأشياء ؟ ماذا لو كان في داخلي برزخ مظلم تتراكم فيه الذكريات المهمة حقا وتتحول ببطء إلى وحول ؟لكني أدرك الآن أن كل ما أضعه في هذا الوعاء الناقص من الكتابة هي ذكريات شاحبة وخواطر غیر كافية . وكلما تلاشت ذکریات ناوكو في داخلی ، ازددت قدرة على التعمق في فهمها . أعرف أيضا لماذا طلبت مني ألا أنساها . كانت ناوگو تعرف بالطبع . كانت تعرف أن ذكرياتي عنها قد تتلاشى . وهذا هو السبب في أنها توسلت إلي ألا أنساها أبدا ، وأن أتذكر أنها كانت موجودة . تكاد تملأني الأفكار بحزن لا يطاق تقريبا ، لأن ناوكو لم تحبني أبدا.ألا ترى ؟ لا يمكن لشخص أن يعتني بآخر أبدا مدى الحياة . أعني افترض أننا تزوجنا، حينئذ لا بد أن تجد عملا خلال النهار، من سيعتني بي حينما لا تكون معي ؟ أو إذا ذهبت في رحلة عمل ، من سيعتني بي حينئذ ؟ هل يمكن أن ألتصق بك في كل دقيقة من حياتنا ؟ أي نوع من التوازن سيكون في ذلك؟ أي نوع من العلاقة ستكون تلك ؟ عاجلا أو آجلا ستجزع مني، ستتساءل عما كنت تفعله بحياتك ، ولماذا تقضي وقتك كله وأنت ترعى هذه المرأة، لن أستطيع احتمال ذلك، ولن يحل هذا الأمر أية من مشاكلي ..ألا ترین ؟ لماذا تكونين صارمة إلى هذا الحد ؟ استرخي ، وضعي عنك هذه الدفاعات. أنت متوترة جدا ولذلك تتوقعين الأسوأ دائما. أريحي جسدك ، وسيضيء الباقي فيك ..قل لي كيف يمكنك قول شيء كهذا . أنت لا تقول شيئا لا أعرفه أصلا . أريحي جسدك وسيضيء الباقي فيك . ما العبرة في قول هذا ؟ إذا أرحت جسدي فقد أتداعي! لقد عشت دائما على هذا النحو ، وتلك هي الطريقة الوحيدة التي أعرفها لأستمر في العيش .. لو أنني استرخيت لحظة ، فلن أجد طريق عودتي مرة أخرى، سأتبعثر قطعاً وتتطاير هذه القطع متفرقة، لماذا لا ترى ذلك ؟ كيف يمكنك الحديث عن رعايتي وأنت لا ترى ذلك ؟قلت : « أعتقد أنني لم أفهمك حقا حتی الآن . لست بالذكاء الذي تتصورين . فهم الأشياء يحتاج مني إلى بعض الوقت . ولكن إذا ما أتيح لي الوقت ، فسأفهمك - أفضل من أي شخص آخر في العالم.ابتسمت ناوکو وهزت رأسها : « کلا ، تكفي اثنتان . إحداهما من أجلك ، أن تدرك كم أنا ممتنة لأنك جئت لتراني هنا . أتمنى أن تفهم مقدار السعادة التي جلبتها لي . أعرف أنها ستنقذني ، إذا كان لشيء أن ينقذني . قد لا أكشف عنها . ولكنها حقيقية ».أريدك دائما أن تتذكرني. هل ستتذكر أنني كنت موجودة، وأنني وقفت إلى جوارك كما هو الحال الآن ؟ أين كان بإمكاننا الاختفاء ؟ وكيف حدث مثل ذلك الأمر ؟ كان يبدو كل شيء مهما استعادته حينئذ ، ناوكو والذات التي كنتها ، والعالم الذي كان بين يدي حينئذ : أين ذهبت هذه كلها ؟ حقا أنني لا أستطيع استدعاء حتى وجهها - في الأقل ليس مباشرة . كل ما بقي لدي هو خلفية ، مشهد خالص ، ليس في واجهته أحد .ونظرت خارج النافذة إلى الغيوم الداكنة المعلقة في بحر الشمال ، مفكراً في كل ما ضيعته في مجرى حياتي : أزمنة مضت إلى الأبد ، أصدقاء ماتوا أو اختفوا، مشاعر لن اذوقها مرة أخرى.غير أنني في الليلة التي مات فيها كيزوكي ، فقدت القدرة على رؤية الموت والحياة بمثل ��ذا الوضوح البسيط. لم يكن الموت نقيض الحياة. كان دائما هنا ، في داخل وجودي، دائما هنا، ولن يسمح لي أي صراع بأن أتناسى وجوده. وحين انتزع الموت کیزوكي ذا السبعة عشر عاما تلك الليلة في مايو انتزعني معه أيضا.الموت موجود، لا بوصفه نقيضا للحياة، بل بوصفه جزءًا منها.لا شيء واحد كان يدور في خلدي حين بدأت حياتي الجديدة في المهجع : التوقف عن أخذ كل شيء بجدية ، وترك مسافة كافية بيني وبين كل شيء آخر .أنا مش عارفه ليه مش فاهمها يعني 🙄🙄نرجع نحب اليابان تاني ولا كأن حصل حاجة في ذهول ورعدة 😂💙💙نفس ا��عند بتاعي ده 🙄😂😂👌🏻22/8/2021 ✅.

Haruki Murakami, el eterno candidato al Nobel. Escritor de fama y prestigio mundial y una auténtica celebridad de las letras en su tierra natal, y claro, yo, lector blasfemo, sin leerme nada de él. Imperdonable. Había que subsanarlo.Decidí iniciarme a través de su novela más célebre e insigne, soy así de intrépido y subversivo, voy a lo afamado: "Tokio Blues. Norwegian Wood.". Conclusión: he alucinado bastante. Mucho, incluso. El nipón, con su escritura, su exposición, sus líneas, te cautiva; es una escritura enigmática e hipnótica. Y en pleno periodo de exámenes, actividad de riesgo.Además, ha sido sorprendente el acercamiento y tratamiento de la sexualidad y la sensualidad, yo, al menos, tenía una visión de la cultura japonesa, de su producción cultural, pudorosa y proclive a la censura (el maldito anime). Y el libro es todo lo contrario: naturalidad, atrevimiento y descaro. Genial, en serio. Flaquezas, y por ello me es imposible concederle la máxima puntuación en estrellas: - Las personalidades de los protagonistas son extremas, a veces, y sin ánimo de desacreditar el trabajo de caracterización, rozan la caricatura. Situaciones y escenarios irreales, ¿en serio estos son chavales de 17-19 años? ¿Filosofan sobre la vida, la muerte, el suicidio y las enfermedades mentales bebiendo brandy? ¿Chicas de 13 años forzando y violentando a mujeres adultas? ¿De verdad?- La reiteración excesiva y el tedio asociado a la misma. Personajes con desenlaces y reflexiones idénticas. - El final. En conclusión, un gran libro, a mí me ha gustado mucho, al principio, casi hasta la mitad, pensaba que iba a ser un 5 estrellas y de lo mejor de la cosecha 2018. Al final un 4,25-4,5. Repetiré con Murakami.

This is the first time I have read one of Murakami’s novels and I am impressed. This book is beautifully written – Murakami’s style is elegant and atmospheric. In Norwegian Wood, he explores love, loss, fear, and memory. As the book opens, protagonist Toru Watanabe is looking back on his college days, seventeen years past. He had moved from Kobe to Tokyo to study at Waseda University after suffering the loss of his best friend, Kizuki, to suicide. The story follows Toru’s relationships with two young women – Naoko, his friend and Kizuki’s girlfriend, and Midori, an eccentric college classmate. Naoko is struggling to overcome severe mental health issues, which leads her to a secluded sanctuary in the countryside. Midori has had a rough early life with parents that paid little attention to her, and she has developed a bold and unconventional approach to life. All three try to overcome painful memories and find their way in the world, some more successfully than others. This is a powerful story about grappling with loneliness and depression. It portrays how sex and love can be both positive and negative forces. Toru attempts to break through grief and find a path to a happier life. He wants to help Naoko get back to the world of the living. Midori holds a more optimistic attitude toward life despite her earlier hardships. The supporting characters are well-developed and lend depth to the narrative. This book stimulates reflection and will linger in my thoughts.

for a book that talks so much about death and suicide (spoilers) is it inappropriate to comment on how much Murakami talks about food?? It’s like food always makes a compelling argument for reasons to keep living, and the way it adds to the sensorial picture of Japan he creates for us. Those little joys, and choosing to enjoy them and choosing find happiness in all things, choosing to live rather than just existing. Life and death are opposites in this either, they’re the middle and the end, parts of the wider process and there’s so much to experience in the meantime. I feel like I should be sadder reading it but we all float through our student years right. Terrible things have happened to the people Toru loves, but we don’t suffer with him in the same way because he chooses to keep going, he chooses to live and experience. I do wonder what happens with him and Midori tho, he knows, but he chooses not to tell us

"Despite your best efforts, people are going to be hurt when it's time for them to be hurt."A coming-of-age story about love, friendship, grief and mental health. This was my first by Haruki Murakami and I absolutely loved his writing. But I probably wouldn't read this book ever again! It was so dark and depressing asf!! I didn't like any of the characters much (and really hate Nagasawa), still the book was really good and engaging!!!
Weird, pretentious, disturbing. Possibly the worst book I've ever read.

In memoria dell'adolescenza rubata "Io a differenza di te ho deciso di vivere, e anche di cercare di vivere bene. Immagino quanto deve essere stata dura per te, ma lo è anche per me, credimi sulla parola. E lo è perché tu sei morto lasciando Naoko in quel modo. Ma io non la abbandonerò così. Perché le voglio bene e perché sono più forte di lei. Ma diventerò ancora più forte di come sono adesso, e più maturo. Diventerò adulto. Devo farlo. Finora ho sempre pensato che avrei voluto oscillare in eterno tra i diciassette e i diciott'anni, ma adesso non lo penso più. Non sono più un ragazzo. Comincio a sentire le responsabilità. Io non sono più quello che tu hai conosciuto. Ho vent'anni ormai. E devo pagare il prezzo per continuare a vivere."Non che io abbia troppa voglia di entrare in società, sia chiaro. Ma dove minchia vanno 'ste dannate anitre, a proposito? Svolazzano sgraziate dal lago di Central Park per dirigersi chissà dove.Pazienza, posso sopravvivere senza saperlo. Teniamo il fascino del mistero; anche perché dall'altra parte sembrano esserci così tante risposte da non saper che pesci pigliare.Mi aspettano altre notti in cui adescare ragazze più confuse e annoiate del sottoscritto.Alla fine il tutto consiste nello svuotarsi le palle e cercare di rimuovere il prima possibile lo squallidume imperante di quelle stanze grigie e spoglie: magari ti becchi pure il cesso otturato e la puzza di fumo, per la cronaca. Se soltanto avessi i soldi di Gatsby per gozzovigliare in qualche festa di sconosciuti e rimirare con sguardo poetico quella luce verde che risplende laggiù...Un giorno riuscirò ad afferrarla, ma non oggi: domani sarà il momento del riscatto.Non siamo forse sospinti senza posa verso il passato?Un calendario vuoto si staglia su una parete disadorna.Nessuna compleanno segnato, nessun impegno; né date cerchiate o avvenimenti da ricordare nel lento incedere dei giorni.L’ambiente ovattato non aiuta a risaltare gesti particolari o momenti che possano imprimersi nella memoria: l’egoismo dell’autoconservazione invoca un testimone che possa provare l’esistenza di chi ha deciso il pozzo come meta definitiva.La vita è potenzialità dell’avvenire, compresa la libertà di interromperla; e cercare giustificazioni degli altrui percorsi è il primo passo per smarcarsi dal ricordo di quelle vite che hanno chiesto l’unica gentilezza di esser ricordate.La dignità della vita resiste sempre, anche nel desiderio di rifiutarla.Ed è giusto agire per egoismo perché solo attraverso il senso di colpa la vita rifiorisce dalla morte.P.S. Ringrazio due persone: Phil, per aver condiviso questo breve e intenso viaggio assieme; Chicca, suggeritrice di titoli indimenticabili.

What a lovely book. This is my second time reading through Norwegian Wood, and I'm still struck at the simplistic, straightforward nature of it all. Once again, Murakami transformed himself from the wacky (A Wild Sheep Chase) and bizarre (Hard-Boiled Wonderland and the End of the World) into a deeply meditative, personal, truthful story about loss, love, and growing-up. Norwegian Wood is a clear winner, and it remains as my favorite work by Murakami (though, I've only read his first five novels, so this may clearly change, especially when I get to The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle and 1Q84).

Was this book a little ego-centric and self-serving? Yes. Did that prevent this book from being another example of Murakami's brilliance? No.Come on, sex so great that two of the women decided never to have sex again because it just couldn't ever compare? Please! Sorry boys, I don't care what your sexual prowess in the bedroom is but no woman would ever come to the conclusion. Ever. With that being said the rest of the book was filled with an insightful and poignant story that pushed Murakami a little further up on my all time list. It was interesting to compare and contrast two different views of suicide having recently finished DFW's Infinite Jest. Two completely different takes on what goes on with someone suicidal and those around them. It was interesting to see it from both sides. Having read "Wind-up" before "Wood" I was able to see the inklings. Able to see H.M. planting seeds in his own subconscious that germinated later into another brilliant insightful book.
اگر قصد خوندن این کتاب فوق العاده رو داشتین، پیشنهاد میکنم ترجمه ای غیر از اینکه من خوندم انتخاب کنین، چون زیاد سانسور شده بود!

"If you only read the books that everyone else is reading, you can only think what everyone else is thinking."Yes, this amazing quote is from Norwegian Wood. It's really something, isn't it. A dream quote. The stuff of magic to be proudly displayed on t-shirts, notebooks and tote bags.I first read this book in 1990s. I'd "discovered" Murakami and fallen into book obsession with him. I would read his books in random order, in awe of his quirkiness. Toru Watanabe is a nineteen year old, attending University in Tokyo at the end of the 1960s. This book is a year in the life, and is all about his thoughts and relationships until he turns twenty.It's quite melancholic and has a slow, underwater feel to it. Toru, his best friend Kizuki and Kizuki's girlfriend Naoko form a tight little clique. Inseparable. Until a tragedy occurs and Toru and Naoku are left to somehow cope with his loss.There's a backdrop of societal change and student uprising. The frienships Toru makes at Uni and the impact they leave on his life.The first time I read this book it left me feeling flat and scratching my head. It was not a favourite then, and revisiting it again after so many years, I feel the same. There are moments where I got glimpses of the Murakami I love. Some beautiful writing. Descriptions of sitting in cafés reading books. Nature's beauty in the changing seasons. His references to music (showing his love of all genres, from classical to jazz and The Beatles - it's only natural this book should be named after one of their quirkier tunes). The joy at starting a new friendship. Discovering what you have in company. There is a white cat called Seagull. These snippets had me settle in and enjoy the book, but they were fleeting. Overall I found this book to be frustrating, as for me it has an air of aimlessness. The characters - with the exception of Toru - are either victims of their own lives or ruthless in their treatment of others. Emotional overload or lack of emotion. Neither extreme is good, and I found it difficult to remain focused on the story from not forming an attachment to any of them. With Toru himself, the isolation he felt (which I could empathise with up to a point) began to grate. It was tough what he went through, but this book felt endless to me.The constant reference to (male) masturbation was boring, as was another character's penchant for watching porn and having extreme sexual fantasties. It was just dull.What was interesting was that Kinokuniya (the amazing bookstore) was mentioned a few times. And this time I knew what it was! There was no Kinokuniya store in Sydney when I first read this, so I got a buzz out of that.⚠️Trigger warnings include suicide, emotional anguish, emotional cruelty, mental health, depression, sexual dysfunction and masturbation. Which shouldn't be a trigger warning in itself, but references to it were incessant.A low watt 3 ⭐ It was simply too many pages for so much existential teen angst.It makes me sad to love an Author so much, only to have some of their books not hit the mark. But that's ok, as I know there are others which more than make up for it.And so, on this rainy Wednesday afternoon I bid adieu to Toru.To end on a positive note, here's another great quote from this book:"Better to be a first-class matchbook than a second class match.Now how good would that look on a t-shirt? My Murakami Odyssey continues with Dance Dance Dance. I'm looking forward to it!As an aside, has anyone else pondered on the line "Just remember, life is a box of chocolates." Sound familiar? I don't know who wrote the screenplay for Forrest Gump, but they must have been a Murakami fan.

Esta es mi segunda lectura de este libro. La primera vez que me lo leí fue hace siete años más o menos y la verdad es que no me gustó nada y no me dejo ningún poso ni recuerdo. Tal vez es que lo leí en una mala época o vete tú a saber. El caso es que ni siquiera lo incluí en mi biblioteca de Goodreads cuando me registré porque ya tenía la idea de volvérmelo a leer, porque me daba la impresión de que le tenía que dar otra oportunidad. El caso es que me ha encantado, no sé qué estaría yo pensando en esa época para no ver lo bien escrito que está, con ese ritmo tan pausado que te va envolviendo y como está todo tan bien perfilado, ya sean paisajes, recuerdos o personajes.Y esta es mi historia con este libro.Esto me da que pensar, porque ¿cuántos libros que no gustaron me gustarían ahora? ¿y al revés? ¿Cuántas estrellas de puntuación se caerían de otros libros?

Cuando comencé este libro no me había leído ni la sinopsis. Lo cogí de la biblioteca porque había visto que era bastante popular y decidí incluirlo en mis tres lecturas que me dejan llevarme al mes.Pues bien, siento llevar la contraria a todos esos afortunados que han disfrutado de este libro, pero a mí este Tokio Blues me ha dejado más bien frío. 🥶 Es cierto que he disfrutado de ciertas partes del libro pero en otras ocasiones se me hizo pesadísimo. Explicaciones larguísimas que no llevan a ningún lado y sobre todo un empalagoso diálogo entre personajes que en más de una ocasión me hizo cortar la lectura y cerrar el libro.Aún así le pongo tres estrellas porque como digo he disfrutado de ciertos pasajes, aunque no me resulte imprescindible haberlo leído. 🥱🥱🥱

Изключително мрачна и депресивна книга, която щеми е трудно да препоръчам, но много харесах! Истински майстор е Мураками! Много трудно ми потръгна четенето на романа, но след първите 50 страници силно ме увлече. Интересен факт е, че оставех ли книгата много трудно посягах към нея. Започнех ли да чета се потапях в света на Мураками и не исках да я оставя. “Норвежка гора” засяга редица значими теми - самотата, депресията, психичното здраве, самоубийството, приятелството, музика, изкуство, любов. Страхотни образи е изградил Мураками - особено женските. Шапки долу. Отнемам 1⭐️, заради прекомерното сексуално съдържание, което никак не е по вкуса ми и твърде многото самоубийства в сюжета. Не знам кога ще посегна пак към Мураками, но когато му дойде времето вероятно ще е “Хроника на птицата с пружина”.

Norwegian Wood has been on my "favorites" shelf for a number of years now, even after several rereads. It never failed to put me in a good mood, despite the fact that the story itself is a rather sad one. It was my first Murakami and also the first "adult" book I've ever read. My mom had got it for me as a birthday gift, possibly as an attempt to make me relate to Japan with something other than Sailor Moon. This was of course reason enough for considerable reluctance on my part, when it came to giving it a try.No one was more surprised than I, when the story ended up growing on me after all. My reasons ranged from the obvious: protagonists barely older than me, freshmen life in university, a 'lot' of sex (well comparatively). And then there were also weird attractions such as: Japanese names. I had previously read stories staring Ion, Christina, Otilia and the rather more exotic Maitreyi. All very special characters in their own right, but with few relatable qualities.Enter Norwegian Wood starring Naoko, Toru, Reiko, Midori; all featured in my favorite anime, yet much more realistic compared to their anime namesakes. They were all doing such mundane things as living in university dorms, playing the guitar, working part time at a music shop, visiting ill relatives in the hospital, cooking 'exotic' food. Truthfully, I haven't reread this book for a number of years now, and after Kafka on the Shore and The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle I probably won't either. It has so many nostalgic moments linked to it, that I'd hate to 'have to' lower its score to a 4. So I'll just quietly pretend that Norwegian Wood is still the best thing since sliced bread: 5/5 stars.

In lots of reviews on Goodreads I read that this early work by Murakami is one of his lesser. That surprises me, because I had a really nice reading experience with it. On the one hand it is a rather conventional "coming of age"-book: we see how a 17 year old boy struggles with life, friendship and love, and above all death. The story is beautifully composed, although the end is a bit predictably moralistic.But the special thing about it is the mood the work breaths: the main character, the young Watanabe, strays through life, searching for his own voice; he's a kind of Man without Qualities: everybody likes him, he is at ease with the most difficult characters, friends (boys and girls) display to him their most profound secrets and confront him with very difficult questions (suicide for instance, or madness). What is really beautiful about Watanabe is his openess and honesty, his authenticity; it's also this quality that makes him find his way through. The strange thing is that everything seems to slide down from him, he has almost no impact upon things, he just undergoes events, but with open eyes. Marvellous how Murakami describes this process.Two other things that make this novel special: persistently there are references to western popculture (especially the Beatles) but also to western high culture (Bach, Camus, Thomas Mann); this produces the effect that the strangeness that sometimes pervades Japanese novels (read by a westerner like me) is effaced. Another thing that is striking is the very explicit way the characters talk about sex or are having sex, always as a natural action, a very nice and human way of interrelating. This was my first acquaintance with Murakami, and I was pleasantly surprised. I've read a few other ones since (see https://www.goodreads.com/review/show..., https://www.goodreads.com/review/show...), and though he has not become my most favourite author, he sure is one of the most interesting writers of the moment. (rating 2.5 stars)

"If you only read the books that everyone else is reading, you can only think what everyone else is thinking."This was my first Murakami and it's easy to see why people are drawn to his writing, it's vulnerable, raw, and relatable. Toru's journey was not one filled with rainbows and unicorns, it was a very dark journey at times and sometimes painful to read, but then there are moments like the ones involving the storm trooper that made me laugh. The prose is beautiful, Toru is a brilliant character full of depth, and I appreciated the stark contrast between Naoko and Midori and the roles they played in his life. I don't generally like ambiguous endings, but this one worked for me. I actually found the ending hopeful which is what I needed it to be since I loved Toru. This is not a book that will be easily forgotten. 4 stars for now, but this may change the more I think about it.
