Correva l'anno  2007 , poi sono arrivati tanti altri libri e tante nuove letture dell'anima, del cuore, dell'intelletto, dell'età sempre mutevole.

2.7 Stars 2.5 stars Let me start by declaring that I’ve read only one book of the author before this one. That’s Kafka on the Shore. I did enjoy it (and even gave it 4 stars), except for the Oedipus parts. While I wasn’t keen on picking this one, I did know that the imagery would be great, and there would be something worth reading. Yeah, I wasn’t entirely wrong, but then, I could have done without this book (at least I could strike off one reading challenge).  The book deals with death, depression, and teenage confusion in a different style. It’s not surprising that I couldn’t relate to any of the characters. But I did expect them to make me feel something, anything. What I was left with instead was an eye roll for Toru, a shake of my head for Midori, and a sigh for Naoko and Reiko. The only reason the book got an extra 0.5 stars (the original was 2.2) was that the author spared Hatsumi for Toru’s conquests (for the lack of a better word). I was dreading their sexual interlude, and thankfully it didn’t happen. Toru and Reiko, I knew it would come (ref: the first paragraph). I wasn’t surprised, not even disappointed, to be honest. The story just didn’t seem to be going anywhere until I was done with half the book. At least, the second half went faster (a bit). Midori was refreshing with her almost surreal character that seemed to be a perfect cover for her vulnerability. Though she has a few scenes I could do without. I mean, there’s a thin line between being delightfully different and stupid. Still, she had some spine, which not even our heroic hero seemed to have. The death of a loved one is never easy to let go of, and Naoko should garner all of my sympathies. Somewhere, she ended up doing the opposite. Stringing a man, oops, a boy along, when knowing there is no hope seems cruel. Reiko started out great, but then we know what happened. Of course, characters with flaws make a book real. This one has every character with glaring flaws. That’s good. But it’s not good too. If there was character development, either progress or decline, I’d have enjoyed their flaws. What do we get instead? The book ends the way it started. We only know that Toru was alive even 18 years after the incidents took place. Guess that should make us happy. With most characters deciding to end their lives, it feels a little good to see the narrator live. I did wonder if he stayed with Midori or went on to find someone else. Either way, he didn’t deserve the girls. A person who cannot let go of the past shouldn’t ruin someone’s future. Sadly, this is very common.  While I have absolutely no issues with sex scenes, I did get irritated by their frequency in this book. I’m wary of men writing women and sex scenes, and this just proved my point again. Ugh! All those blowjobs and girls fantasizing about men’s (oops again), boys’ dicks get annoying after a while. There’s only so much one can read about Toru sleeping with girls or dreaming about sleeping with Naoko. I still gave the book 2+ stars because it does talk about depression, self-obsessed people like Nagasawa and the kind of bullying one has to endure if they are different from the rest (Storm Tropper). Storm Tropper, somehow, was the only character who held promise, and he was plucked out of the book, just like that. To sum up (I need to do it before I go on ranting), Norwegian Wood should definitely not be the first Murakami book a person should read. Pick up Kafka on the Shore. It’s a lot better in plot, style, and narration.

The novel is based on the suicide problem in young people - which is apparently endemic in Japanese culture - and the attendant mental illness that leads them to utter despair.The narrator (a guy) has only two best friends at school: a guy and a girl, who are also a romantic couple. When the guy commits suicide at 17, the narrator by sheer chance finds himself comforting and taking care of the girl who starts to behave oddly after the tragedy, apparently due to sadness, but things turn for the worse when the girl suffers mental breakdown and gets admitted to a sanatorium for treatment. The rest of the story is the narrator’s attempt to put things to right and to bring the girl back to normal life - so at its heart it's a heartfelt love story.It’s written in straightforward first person narrative and avoids the sort of surrealist storytelling flourishes Murakami is known for in his other major novels "Kafka on the Shore" and "The Wind-up Bird Chronicle" - it's more grounded in realist mode. However, there are a few things that got me thinking.Murakami makes tons of references to Western classical music and American pop. The books which feature in the story, too, are mostly Western. Shouldn’t a novel about Japanese people set in Japan and written in Japanese should be more grounded in the Japanese culture, music and literature? One character who is a good maverick musician only plays Mozart and Bach and Beatles. The name of the novel itself is derived from Beatles’ song. The mentally ill girl liked the song and that is the only justification for naming the book so.Sex is a recurrent theme. At times it feels the author is taking great pains, figuratively speaking, in describing the repetitive sexual encounters of his characters even when situations don’t call for it. In this novel everyone is trying to do it with everyone else. But I guess our modern readers don't think a work of fiction as well-rounded unless the story comes with a few erections and orgasms.That aside, I thoroughly enjoyed reading it. It's studded with beautiful sentences, startling interpretive utterances revealing complex situations with great ease - and for that one must appreciate the translator. It's a well-written, sad, moving and, at times, gripping story worth your time and money.

U poslednje vreme mnogo radim i nemam vremena za čitanje, koje je inače ostalo jedina hrana i radost mog bića tako da možete zamislisti u kakvom sam stanju. No, pošto je posao (poslovi zapravo) kojim se bavim intelektualno ne zahtevan ostavlja mi mozak sasvim slobodnim i umesto da se bavim crnim mislima odlučio sam slušati knjige. Nisam to posebno često praktikovao ranije, ali eto sada počeh i super mi je. "Ubiti pticu rugalicu" sam takođe odslušao, iako je imam na papiru...Dok sam slušao uglavnom sam mislio koliko je momenat u kome neku knjigu zgrabite bitan, da sam "Norvešku šumu" počeo pre samo nekoliko meseci verovatno bi mi bila težak smor, hipstersko onanisanje i tome slično. Avaj, sada, dok ne mislim da mi je život skockan i sav na svom mestu, baš mi je legla. Ja svakako ne čitam zbog zapleta i tog nestrpljivog isčekivanja šta će da bude šta će da bude, pa mi ni ovde ne smeta što je ovo samo komad nekih života nekih mladih skenjanih ljudi koji se beznadežno vuku kroz postojanje ili čak ni to ne uspevaju...

یک یا دو سال پیش شروع کردمش. ۲۰۰ و خورده ای صفحه خواندم و بعد نیمه رهایش کردم. روندش خیلی کند بود و یکجورهایی مثل سوکورو تازاکی بی رنگ همه چی مربوط به گذشته و درباره‌ی گذشته بود و آرام آرام پیش می‌رفت. تا اینکه چند روز پیش سعی کردم دوباره برش دارم، و دیدم چقدر عاشقش هستم!چقدر ساده در عین حال ملموس و زیبا بود. احساسات انسانی و فوق العاده‌ای که موراکامی توصیف کرده بود قلبم را لمس کرد!فهمیدم بسته به درک آدم است. مثل ۱۳ سالگی که مادام بواری خواندم و بعدش گفتم خدامرگم این چه کتابی بود؟!خب، طول می‌کشد تا آدم بزرگ شود و بفهمد چیزهای پیچیده‌ ای در دنیا هست که از توصیف دختر های خوب حرف گوش کن در چمن زاران زیبا حقیقی تر است. خیلی هم حقیقی تر است.

Un obra sutil, llena de imágenes hermosas y personajes entrañables. Murakami nos cuenta una historia sobre la pérdida de la inocencia, la entrada a la realidad de la adultez, la desilusión sobre los ideales de juventud, todo contado con la música de The Beatles de fondo. Una obra poética, llena de sensibilidad, que te regresa al fin de la adolescencia, a ese momento en que te das cuenta que eres un adulto más en el mundo de adultos al que siempre te resististe pertenecer.Recomendado a todo el mundo.
حزين أنها إنتهت مورا كاتبى الأثير

4.5 estrellas.vaya, vaya. no sé por dónde comenzar esta reseña. en primera, decir que me estaba tardando en leer este libro porque es sencillamente magnífico. me gustó mucho y fue agradable conocer el estilo particular de Murakami, o al menos el más sencillo, ya que me han comenzado a decir que en otros libros raya más en lo metafórico y filosófico. aunque le prometí a un amigo leerlo de manera más lenta, se puede decir que lo cumplí en parte, pero tampoco demasiado porque el libro es realmente corto, y el mismo te va envolviendo y quedas atrapado por estos personajes tan singulares y entrañables: toru Watanabe, con esa forma particular de ver la vida, que disfruta la soledad, tiene una forma particular de expresarse y muy inteligente; Midori, una chica que es compañera de él en historia de Teatro y con quien consigue una intimidad emocional increíble, la verdad es que su manera de pensar era muy madura, y me nutrían y disfrutaba las conversaciones que tenía con watanabe, sin malicia, llenas de pensamientos, emociones, psicología e intelecto; Naoko, chica de quien Toru está enamorado pero que carga consigo problemas psicológicos y se lamenta por el amor de su vida, Kizuki. Aún así, antes de todo ello, también era una chica despierta, y con quien nuestro protagonista solía pasarla bien.El libro puede que sea quizás uno de los más sonados y lo cataloguen como el ideal para introducirse al autor, aunque esté más marketinnizado, lo cierto es que debo reconocer que está muy bien escrito. retrata la época de la música de los 70's, incluso el último año de los Beatles. como dato curioso, mencionar que Haruki Murakami se inspiró en la canción de Norwegian wood para ambientar su libro, y lo cierto es que le quedó muy bien. de hecho, es esa canción lo que hace que Watanabe nos lleve a través del recuerdo por esos años de juventud.Lo único que no me gustaba mucho de él es  ese afán de buscar acostarse con otras mujeres, como si fuera algo necesario con el que no pudiese vivir, y más si se hacía estar enamorado de Naoko , aunque en este punto vamos a decir que es muy subjetivo porque yo tengo mi propia forma de pensar en cuanto a ese tema, mas no quiere decir que no sea capaz de entenderlo.Tokio blues es un libro muy dialogado, en cada momento del mismo aparece siempre hablando e interactuando con alguien, tal como todo chico social. Irónicamente, había momentos en los que describía la sensación de soledad, pese a contar con gente que lo apreciaba: su amigo nagasawa, kizuki  cuando estaba vivo , Naoko, Reiko, Midori... A través del diálogo conocemos a cada personaje, ya que ellos mismos nos hacen partícipes de sus historias de vida, sus pensamientos y sentimientos. está demás decir que los de Watanabe los conocemos de sobra, pues además de todo, él es quien nos narra la historia.Y no puedo dejar de comentar este otro aspecto. el libro habla sobre sexo de una manera tan natural y fluida, sin la menor intención de caer en tabú ni mucho menos de tocarlo de una manera vulgar o sucia. No, lo habla como si fuera algo tan común como comer, cepillarse los dientes o dormir. aquí un ejemplo. —¿He llegado demasiado pronto? —preguntó ella—. ¿Te acabas de levantar?—Voy a lavarme la cara y a afeitarme. ¿Me esperas unos quince minutos? —le rogué.—No me importa esperarte, pero, desde hace un rato, no paran de mirarme las piernas.—Normal, ¿no te parece? Presentándote en una residencia de chicos con una falda tan corta... Vamos, te mirarán todos.—No hay problema. Hoy llevo unas bragas muy bonitas. De color rosa, con un encaje precioso.—Peor aún. —Suspiré.Me lavé la cara y me afeité lo más rápido posible. Luego me puse una camisa azul, una chaqueta de tweed gris por encima, bajé y conduje a Midori a la salida de la residencia. Estaba bañado en un sudor frío.—¿Todos los chicos que hay aquí se masturban? —Midori alzó la vista hacia la residencia.—Es probable.—¿Lo hacen pensando en chicas?—Supongo que sí —dije—. No creo que haya ningún hombre que se masturbe pensando en el mercado de valores, en la conjugación de los verbos o en el canal de Suez. Imagino que la mayoría lo hace pensando en mujeres.—¿El canal de Suez?—Por ejemplo.—Es decir, piensan en una chica determinada.—¿Por qué no se lo preguntas a tu novio? —le espeté—. No entiendo a qué viene preguntarme todas estas cosas un domingo por la mañana.—Es simple curiosidad —contestó Midori—. Además, él se enfadaría muchísimo. Dice que las mujeres no tenemos que preguntar estas cosas.—Es una manera de pensar muy correcta.—Pero yo quiero saberlo. ¿Tú, cuando te masturbas, piensas en una chica concreta?—Yo sí. Ahora bien, no tengo ni idea de lo que hacen los demás —me resigné a responder.—¿Y has pensado alguna vez en mí? Dime la verdad. No me enfadaré.—No, nunca, la verdad —le respondí honestamente.—¿Y por qué no? ¿No me encuentras atractiva?—No es eso. Eres atractiva, eres guapa, te gusta provocar.—Entonces, ¿por qué no piensas en mí?—En primer lugar, porque te veo como una amiga y no puedo involucrarte en mis fantasías sexuales. En segundo lugar...—Hay otra persona que está presente en tus pensamientos. —La verdad es que sí —reconocí.—Eres educado incluso en esto —comentó Midori—. Me gusta esta faceta tuya. Pero, aunque sea una vez, ¿me incluirás a mí en tus fantasías sexuales o en tus obsesiones? Me gustaría aparecer. Te lo pido como amiga. ¡Vamos! Esto a otro no se lo pediría. Esta noche, cuando te masturbes, piensa en mí. No puedo pedírselo a cualquiera. Pero tú eres un amigo. Y luego quiero que me cuentes cómo ha ido.Lancé un suspiro.—Pero nada de penetración, ¿eh? Somos amigos. Mientras no haya penetración, puedes hacer lo que quieras. Pensar lo que quieras. cita larga, lo sé, pero debo admitir que cuando leía esta parte, así como otras haciendo alusión al tema, quedaba sorprendido de la naturalidad con que se llevaba todo esto.Por esto, es que me parece que el libro es bastante ameno, disfrutable, muy anímico y psicológico, como en  la escena en la que muere Naoko y Toru se siente culpable por dejarla, o también en la carta en la que midori le escribe a él cuando estaban tomando una coca-cola y le recriminaba su falta de atención hacia ella Lo recomiendo ampliamente.

There's something magical about Murakami's books, something that keeps you going, something that doesn't make sense, yet, makes perfect sense. There's something about Murakami's books that I can't find in others' books. 
"Those guys sure knew something about the sadness of life, and gentleness." By "those guys" Reiko of course meant John Lennon, Paul Mc Cartney and George Harrison.
The Beatles are my favourite band of all time. I can listen to their songs all day, everyday, and never get bored. Their music is ethereal and eternal, which is also something I can say for Murakami's books. I've read three, so far, each of them so different from the others, yet as beautiful and soulful as the other. Of course, it is here that I should point out that Murakami's books have some common themes; I mean to say characters, but seeing as all his characters seem to represent a theme, I stand by my reasoning. Toru Watanabe is an introverted, slightly odd college student who is in love with the beautiful and certifiably crazy Naoko. Of course, she (like the other women in this opus) is a manic pixie dreamgirl.The song Norwegian Wood was revolutionary. It was the first rock song to incorporate the sitar in its music, and to this day, it remains iconic of the Beatles' innovation and creativity, while simultaneously reflecting the simple and enjoyable music that they are known for. This book, similarly, while drastically different from the usual Murakami style, propelled him to superstardom. Now, having read two other books of his, The Wind-up Bird Chronicle and Kafka on the Shore, both of which were obviously rampant in the classic Murakami themes of magical realism and surrealism, this book was surprisingly more realistic and, well, normal. Of course, because Murakami is drawn to magical realism like a moth to a flame, there are underlying themes of death and a slightly preternatural element to it in some parts. But in its heart, it is a simple, romantic, coming-of-age story. 
"For a certain kind of person, love begins from something tiny or silly. From something like that or it doesn't begin at all."
The song Norwegian Wood is a story of an affair that John Lennon had, and while it may just seem like it is Naoko's favourite song, I like to think that it has a much deeper connotation to the themes of the story. Sometime back, I saw the video version of Bohemian Rhapsody, where the whole song was played out as a small movie. I like to believe that Murakami heard this song, and decided, "hey, I can make a story out of this". Because in a way, the book Norwegian Wood is a more complete version of its eponymous song. It is a surprisingly simple book dealing with deeply complex themes of love, loss, life, and living. The characters in the book are realistic enough for you to hate them at various points of time during the book, and I don't mean hate them in an endearing manner. The most incredible part of the book, however, is its vivid imagery. Whether it be the natural scenery, food, the weather, of emotions, Murakami (and the translator) has done a stellar job with the descriptions and the language. Of course, there are some weird sex scenes and 
a lot
 of penis talk, but my previous experience and hearsay otherwise have prepared me for that. Read Norwegian Wood for the rich descriptions and the depth of its characters. because despite its many obvious flaws, these two factors make this book a five-star read for me. I also live for pop culture references, and this one has them aplenty. Of course, the fact that Watanabe doesn't much like The Graduate, which is my favourite movie slightly irritated me, but oh well, he was kind of a prick anyway.
All of us (by which I mean all of us, both normal and not-so-normal) are imperfect human beings living in an imperfect world. We don't live with the mechanical precision of a bank account or by measuring all our lines and angles with rulers and protractors.

Σκέφτηκα πραγματικά πολύ για το ποιο βιβλίο θα ήθελα να είναι το πρώτο της χρονιάς. Όχι γιατί απαραίτητα θα κάνει τη διαφορά αλλά δεν ξέρω μάλλον γιατί ενδόμυχα μέσα μου δεν ήθελα να βιώσω την «κατάρα του βιβλιοφάγου» να ξεκινήσω τη χρονιά με ένα άθλιο βιβλίο και μετα να συνεχιστεί και για όλο το υπόλοιπο έτος. Χτες λοιπόν αφού ξεφύλλισα 3-4 βιβλία (εντάξει σταματήστε με πιάσατε ήταν παραπάνω) έπεσα πάνω στο νορβηγικό δάσος του Μουρακάμι. Είχα καιρό να διαβάσω κάτι δικό του και η αλήθεια είναι ότι περισσότερο το ξεκίνησα έχοντας τη βεβαιότητα ότι θα το άφηνα όπως και τα υπόλοιπα. Αν σκεφτώ ότι κόντεψα να αλλάξω χρόνο με το μουρακάμι και όχι με την οικογένεια μου υποθέτω πως οι φόβοι μου δεν είχαν βάση . Και ναι τελικά τα κατάφερα. Δε θα μπορούσα να ζητήσω καλύτερη εκκίνηση πραγματικά!!! 5 γεμάτη ζάχαρη άχνη αστεράκια!!! Είχα στα αλήθεια ξεχάσει πόσο σπουδαίος αφηγητής είναι ο Μουρακάμι. Πραγματικά πρέπει να σαι καλός συγγ��αφέας ώστε να επιτυγχάνεις ένα βιβλίο το οποίο στερείται ιδιαίτερης πλοκής να σε καθηλώνει και να καταπίνεις ως αναγνώστης τις σελίδες λες και ο χρόνος γύρω σου έχει σταματήσει. ΤΟ Νορβηγικό δάσος φέρει τη σφραγίδα του συγγραφέα του και αποτελεί δείγμα της συγγραφικής του ευφυίας μέσα από την σχεδόν λυρική και ποιητική του αφήγηση.Το Νορβηγικό δάσος είναι ένα βιβλίο όπου ο έρωτας και ο θάνατος πορεύονται χέρι χέρι υπό τους ήχους της μουσικής. Είναι μια αριστοτεχνική θα έλεγα διείσδυση στον ψυχισμό του ανθρώπου. Ένα μελαγχολικό και νοσταλγικό μυθιστόρημα για τον ανεκπλήρωτο έρωτα από τη μοναδική πένα του Μουρακάμι. Το νορβηγικό δάσος λοιπόν αποτελεί το βιβλίο του έρωτα και του θανάτουΟ θάνατος του Κιζούκι με είχε διδάξει κάτι, μιά πίστη που ένιωθα ότι την είχα κάνει δική μου, κομμάτι του εαυτού μου: ο θάνατος υπάρχει, όχι ως το αντίθετο της ζωής αλλά ως μέρος της. Ζώντας καθένας τη ζωή του, τρέφουμε τον θάνατο. Μα όσο κι αν αυτό είναι αλήθεια, δεν είναι παρά μία μόνο από τις αλήθειες που πρέπει να μάθουμε. δεν υπάρχει αλήθεια ικανή να γιατρέψει τη λύπη. Δεν υπάρχει ούτε αλήθεια ούτε εντιμότητα ούτε δύναμη ούτε καλοσύνη ούτε τίποτα που να μπορεί να γιατρέψει αυτή τη λύπη. Πρέπει να την αντέξουμε ως το τέλος και να μάθουμε κάτι απ’ αυτή. Μα ό, τι κι αν μάθουμε, δεν θα μας βοηθήσει την επόμενη φορά που μια παρόμοια λύπη θα έρθει να μας συντρίψει απροειδοποίητα. Ο 37χρονος Τόρου Βατανάμπε, καθώς το αεροπλάνο του προσγειώνεται στο Αμβούργο, ακούει μια διασκευή του τραγουδιού των Beatles "Νορβηγικό δάσος". Είναι το τραγούδι αυτό που τον μεταφέρει 20 χρόνια πριν στην εποχή της ενηλικίωσης του. Κάπως έτσι ξεκινάει να περιγράφει τη ζωή του όπως εκείνη διαμορφώθηκε μεταξύ των 17 και 20. Στα χρόνια αυτά θα γίνει μάρτυρας πολλών και διαφορετικών γεγονότων, θα βιώσει αυτοκτονίες πολλών και κοντινών του προσώπων, θα γνωρίσει την αγάπη και το θάνατο ως μέρος της ζωής, θα πορευτεί μόνος του όχι τόσο γιατί του αρέσει η μοναξιά αλλά γιατί όπως λέει σιχαίνεται τις απογοητεύσεις, είναι πιστός στις αρχές του αλλά και συνάμα θα γευτεί τους πειρασμούς που βρίσκονται μπροστά μου. Ένας νέος που μέσα σε αυτά τα 3 χρόνια θα γνωρίσει τη ζωή σε όλες τις εκφάνσεις της και θα γίνει άντρας. Ο Τόρου Βαντανάμπε θα κληθεί να επιλέξει ανάμεσα στη ζωή και το θάνατο, ανάμεσα στο παρελθόν και το μέλλον αφού πρώτα μάθει να αποδέχεται όλα τα στάδια της ζωής από την ίδια τη ζωή, τις απολαύσεις, τον πόνο και τις απογοητεύσεις της μέχρι το θάνατο. Ένα βιβλίο που χωρίς να λέει πολλά στην πραγματικότητα σημαίνει άλλα τόσα και που θα ταρακουνήσει τις καρδιές των απαιτητικών αναγνωστών.

تحتاج عقلاً فوق عقلك لتقرأ موراكامي كما يريدك أن تقرأه، من خلال الغياب المفاجئ من حوله، نستكشف مشاعر تورو واتانابي الذي يقف صامدًا بينما تتساقط ذكرياته مفجوعة و مشوشة بكل الموت من حولها، موراكامي يصنع من تورو بديلاً في مخطط الآخرين كما في علاقة صديقة كيزوكي - المنتحر- و ناوكو الفتاة التي وقع تورو في حبها، و في علاقته ب رايكو المرأة الثلاثينية المطلقة و علاقته بميدوري الفتاة الصاخبة- صاحبة الشخصية المسلية هنا- بحبيبها كان البديل كذلك، تورو يبحث عن النضج و الحب، فكيف يجدهما في زوبعة الغياب هذه، إن كان كلما حولك من أشخاص يغيبهم الموت فأنت ممن يحق لهم التساؤل هل هم من أصبحوا في عالم آخر فعلاً أم أنت من أنتقلت لبعد آخر؟ إن كنت لم تشعر بانتقالك فهل من المنطقي أنك تحللت شيئًا فشيئًا دون أن تشعر ؟ خسارتك لمن حولك ممن يهمك أمرهم و يهمهم أمرك هو تحلل في ذاتك! خسارتك لذاكرتك بثقل ما تحويه عنك هو تحلل ينقلك لبعد آخر ! بداية الرواية و قفلتها شيء عظيم و مربك بحيث لا يجد القارئ تفسيرات مقنعة ولائقة بما قرأ، يكفي أن تتذرع بكمية الجنس أو الغموض عند موراكامي لتقلع عن محاولة فهمه، لكنك تأكد حينها كم ستخسر. لا يهمني كم أخفق في فهم مقاصده و لكن هذا الكاتب استثناء.أقتبس من غابته:- الذاكرة شيء مضحك.- تلك هي الأشياء الأولى، و إنها لتأتي بوضوح مطلق.- أحيانًا أفكر أن في قلبي نواة قاسية، لا يدخلها شيء على الأطلاق، و انني لأشك في قدرتي على حب أي انسان.- إذا كنت تقرأ الكتب التي يقرأها كل شخص سواك فقط، فلن تستطيع التفكير إلا بالطريقة التي يفكر بها كل شخص سواك. وهذا يعني عالم الريفين و السذج، الناس الحقيقيون يشعرون بالعار لأنهم يفعلون ذلك.- حين تكون محوطًا بإمكانيات لا نهاية لها، فإن من أصعب الأشياء عليك تركها تفلت من يديك.- الكتابة ��ندي عملية مؤلمة.-مهما قلنا، فلن يصدق الناس إلا ما يريدون تصديقه، وكلما ازددنا مكافحة، ازداد وضعنا حرجًا.--يترك الناس ذكريات غريبة، صغيرة وراءهم حين يموتون.- انظر، العالم مكان ظالم بالفطرة، لم أكتب قوانينه، لقد كان دائمًا على هذا النحو." لا بد أنه شيء رائع أن تكوني متأكدة من أنكِ تحبين شخصاً ما" - حين تبدأ من الصفر، فقد حصلت على ما تتعلمه.- أبريل، أكثر وحشة من أن تقضيه وحدك بطوله.- جميعنا كائنات إنسانية ناقصة تعيش في عالم يعوزه الكمال.- إذا كنت لا تريد ان تقضي عمرك في مأوى مجانين ، فعليك أن تنفتح قليلاً و تجري مع الحياة في تدفقها الطبيعي.- لا تقلق، إنه مجرد موت، فلا تتركه ينغص عليك حياتك.- يوجد الموت لا بوصفه نقيض للحياة، بل بوصفه جزء منها.- ليست هذه نقودًا، إنها مشاعري، لا تفكر فيها كثيرًا، خذها فحسب.- ذاكرتي بقيت مشتبكة مع الموتى، لا الأحياء.- ليست الرسائل سوى قطع من الورق، أحرقيها، و سيبقى ما في القلب في القلب، احتفظي بها وسيختفي ما يختفي.

Lâu lắm mới gặp lại Midori, rồi Naoko, rồi Nagasawa.Gặp lại nhau vào tháng 8 chứ không phải là một cuộc marathone tháng 9 như mọi lần nên lại càng lạ lùng, nhất là vào những ngày Hà Nội thời tiết khó chịu như bây giờ.Rừng Nauy có khi là một phần tuổi trẻ của rất nhiều người đọc Việt Nam, của nhiều người viết Việt Nam, trong đó có tôi.Một câu chuyên minh chứng cho việc: kể cả với câu chuyện tuyệt đối đơn giản, hoặc tuyệt đối vô nghĩa, nhưng với sự khéo léo của một người dẫn chuyện đại tài, bằng những phá cách khiến người ta kinh ngạc vẫn có thể làm cho câu chuyện ấy trở nên dịu dàng và đáng nhớ hơn bao giờ hết.Tất cả chúng ta đều viết dễ dàng hơn khi có Murakami. Hãy cảm ơn ông vì điều đó.Tôi không bàn đến kết thúc, bắt đầu của mỗi nhân vật trong câu chuyện này. Ai cũng nhìn thấy bản thân mình đâu đó trong mỗi nhân vật đó. Ấy là phần còn thiếu của chúng ta khi đọc sách. Nhiều người cố gắng đi phân tích họ. Tôi thấy đó là một việc làm hết sức nực cười.Ngay cả bản thân khi Murakami bắt đầu câu chuyện này (với mục đích chỉ là 1 chuyện ngắn có tên Đom Đóm) ông cũng không thế biết được kết cục của nhân vật đến đâu cho đến khi kết thúc đến dòng cuối cùng.Vậy thì ta làm sao mà hiểu được cơ chứ?

"Beautiful flawed characters", they say. "Love story", they say. Some even say "Murakami's best work". All I can see is that this guy, Toru Watanabe, gets a lot of action. Some behavior analysis here : what made this book so famous? Put adolescence, suicide, a loner protagonist who reads and listens to cool music (instant likey anyone?) , a bit of youth angst, some conversations to make the book look a bit substantial, some essence of so-called-love and a hell lot of sexual fantasies to jerk off : sex with beautiful girls at bar, swapping sexual partners, oral, sex with best friend's girl, sex with random chick as a favor to her, sex with a nymphomaniac, sex with someone much elder to you, and oh, also closet lesbian sex. You name it, this book has it. No wonder it is famous. Murakami struck the right note. Definitely a recommended read for ostentatious readers who can put a status update about it and proclaim themselves Murakami fans. Anyway, in the end, Toru sort of has a screw loose. What else to expect? Issued in public interest : Don't have sex at your lover's funeral. I swear if my guy does something like that, I will come out of the grave, grudge movie style.

رمانی خوش خوان است باترجمه ای روان . چوب نروژی و چند آهنگ دیگر گروه موسیقی موردعلاقه من بیتلزدرکتاب اجرمیشود و موردعلاقه یکی ازقهرمانان است . یکی دوداستان عاشقانه که ضلع سوم برخی یک فردمرده است . روحیات وروابط شخصیتهای جوان دراین کتاب که دردهه 60 میلادی ژاپن میگذرد تاحدی مثل نسل دهه شصتی خودمان است .دختران وپسرانی با دیدی متفاوت به زندگی . قبلا " هم ازکسی شنیده بودم که فرهتگ دهه شصت آمریکا ، اکنون درایران غالب است وسریال آمریکایی رامثال می آورد که اخیرا " بامحوریت خانواده ها ی آمریکایی دردهه شصت ساخته شده است (نامش رابخاطرندارم ) .نگاهی جالب راجع به مرگ دراین کتاب مطرح میشود. فصل هشت آن برایم باتکیه بر یکی ازشخصیتها به نام "نازاگاوا" جالب بود.نمونه همان خلقیاتی که من دربین جوانان امروزایران می بینم . اشاراتی به گروههای مارکسیستی و به نظرمیرسد قسمتهای سانسورشده ازروابط انسانی هم دارد . ظاهرا" گربه هم بایدهمیشه نقشی درکتابهای موراکامی دارد. قبلا " کافکادرکرانه راخوانده بودم.امروزفیلمش راهم به زبان ژاپنی زیرنویس فارسی دیدم.خوب بود.کمک میکرد به درک بهترنکات سانسورشده.

WHAT. A. READ. Mind officially blown. I loved Murakami already, and this book just made me love him even more. I think what I love most is his elusiveness. You finish the book and you think 'wow, that was so powerful', but then, when you try to grasp exactly what it was that made you think that, it's almost impossible. It's a story about loss and nostalgia, but also about the secret strangeness of others. Simple incidents are suddenly laden with meaning, but it's difficult to figure out why. Knowing me, I'll ponder it over for a year or so, then read it again. It's one of those marvellous books that demands a second read!

There's a lot of things going on in my mind after finishing this and I don't know exactly from where I can start talking about this book. When I was in the last page I was like "wait, what! Is it over? How?" It feels like I was there in the book and everything was happening in front of my eyes. So surreal, so beautiful! Words are less to describe this book.This is the kind of book that motivates you, makes you want to keep exploring more and more Murakami. If anybody ask me what is your favourite book, I will say "Norwegian Wood" even without blinking my eyes.I made my own playlist while I was reading this book. Every single song is just amazing ❤

واقعیتش نمی‌دونم دقیقا چه حسی به رمان دارم ولی با همه‌ی کاراکتر‌های داستان ارتباط برقرار و همذات‌پنداری کردم چون برای من همگی از دنیای واقعی می‌اومدند و در نتیجه برام ملموس و زنده بودند. شکل‌گیری و تحول داستان کند اما در عین حال جذاب بود. کتاب رو در عرض یک ماه و خرده‌ای خوندم چون به طور ناخودآگاهی می‌خواستم با داستان و شخصیت‌هاش بیشتر زندگی کنم و لذت ببرم. از این نکته هم غافل نشم که با موسیقی‌های زیادی که تو کتاب اسمشون اومده - که به نظرم از نقاط قوت اصلی کتابه - پلی لیست درست کردم و بسی کیف می‌کنم.🤭در نهایت کتاب رو به کتاب‌خوان‌های عزیز پیشنهاد میکنم.

ترجمه فارسى كه ماشالله به ساسنسور و ترجمه😁😁 دو ماه طول کشید برسم صفحه ٥٠، و از اون به بعد، با اینکه از پی‌دی‌اف نفرت دارم متن اصلى رو خوندم، كتاب خيلى فضاش افسرده‌س، و درعين‌حال پُر از حر‌‌ف‌هاى قشنگه و با وجود اينكه اتفاق خاصى نميفته جذابه. ولى همچنان کافکا در کرانه بهترین کتاب موراکامیِ برام.
Un libro sencillo y a la vez complejo que te llena y te vacía. Ha sido una lectura muy especial. Ah, y con él he aprendido que sé leer mientras camino.
Άφωνος. Τι ξέρω εγώ για να μπορέσω να μιλήσω;
thank you God for blessing us with Murakami, his beautiful writing and translators.

Have you ever seen a dead body?Dying is like falling asleep. I learned it when I visited the morgue after my grandfather died in April last year. He had such a peaceful face and if it weren’t for the evident pallor of his skin, he would have looked like he was just resting. His lips were perfectly joined together, his head was laid on soft pillows, his bony fingers were locked around a rosary. He asked for himself the humblest of coffins, and to be remembered by his loved ones as someone who did everything he could for his family. When I think of him, I think of Tokyo Story (東京物語 : Tōkyō Monogatari), a 1953 Japanese film by Yasujirō Ozu that I watched the morning after he died — and that you should watch, too — as well as of Norwegian Wood (ノルウェイの森 : Noruwei no Mori), which I read the following week. The two of them are important pieces of both cinematography and post-modern literature.Murakami’s stories, as Matthew C. Strecher points out in “Magical Realism and the Search for Identity in the Fiction of Murakami Haruki”, fit perfectly into the general category of “magic realism”, a style of literary fiction featuring a realistic view of the world while also adding magical elements, therefore the lines between fantasy and reality appear blurred. However, oddly enough, “magic realism” has nothing to do with Norwegian Wood, and its story appears so real that it hurts and comforts you at the same time. At the beginning of the novel, the narrator Watanabe Tōru says that he perfectly remembers the April days during which the story is set and I was stunned to read that. I’m not one to believe in fate, but there was something about me reading this book in that exact month after my grandpa passed away that I can’t get out of my mind. Just like I couldn’t get the song Norwegian Wood by the Beatles out of my mind. And it’s still there, somewhere. Norwegian Wood is a coming-of-age novel about time passing and growing older, about leaving the past behind without forgetting about those who helped us in making it memorable for better or worse, because first and foremost experience is what shapes our personality and identity. This is suggested by many quotes throughout the book: "The dead will always be dead, but we have to go on living." ; "I want you to always remember me. Will you remember that I existed, and that I stood next to you here like this?" — death is not something opposed but intrinsic to life. Murakami deeply understands the human mind in the form that he envisions it as dark, cold, and mysterious. In Norwegian Wood the consciousness of each individual is a character itself and depression appears as a dominant aspect of the mind. Nietszche would say “To live is to suffer, to survive is to find some meaning in the suffering.” In recent times I found these words to be true, but if there’s something I’ve learned after my grandpa passed away, it is that persistence defeats suffering, therefore one must face the pain. Murakami's characters are brutally honest, even when dealing with something so “immature” as love. Tōru is compared to Salinger's Holden and, at times, to Fitzgerald's Jay Gatsby. In fact, a nice comparison also present in the book sees Tōru helplessly staring at the flame that flickers slightly just like Jay Gatsby every night looking at that little light across the bay. Indeed, almost every character in this novel waits for the other. Naoko waits to be reunited with Kizuki even though she loves Tōru, Midori waits for Tōru to reciprocate her feelings, and in the end even Tōru waits for Midori to get her call once he is ready to forget Naoko so that he can love Midori. Time passes and past opportunities remain lost in the past. There is no turning back, only looking ahead. It seemed to me that Murakami’s characters are, therefore, passive, lost in themselves seeking to find the Self in their inner minds, making identity a matter of will. Murakami’s characters also wish to find intimacy in each other’s warmth, a kind of understanding that seems impossible due to the complications of human life. Their souls scream interminably for happiness and security, something unreachable and for this reason desperately wanted. In fact, we as human beings have pleasure as a core desire. We desire an abstract kind of pleasure that we believe to be completeness with the other, yet we are scared of it like hedgehogs. By approaching the other, the hedgehogs will inevitably hurt each other with their respective spines. In this way, if platonic intimacy becomes even more difficult to achieve, sexual intimacy is unattainable. “I was always hungry for love. Just once, I wanted to know what it was like to get my fill of it -- to be fed so much love I couldn’t take any more. Just once.” This way, the main conflict becomes internalized; the main characters are but fighting themselves. This, I believe, is what makes Norwegian Wood so special.“I don't care what you do to me, but I don't want you to hurt me. I've had enough hurt already in my life. More than enough. Now I want to be happy.”When my other very much loved grandpa passed away in January of this year, I thought of Norwegian Wood more than I should’ve. A few years ago, he’d tell me “Smile a lot, always be happy even during the hardest of times. It hurts me to see you sad, so be happy” and, of course, I broke the promise right after. But as I said, persistence is what defeats pain, and ever since then I always try my best to see the world from a different perspective. I’m so sorry to sadden y’all with my reviews, but my Norwegian Wood rant has been sitting in my computer for almost a year now. This time I’m aware it came out rather short. Murakami made me simultaneously hate and love this novel. I am well aware of its female characters, but when I read it the first time, I thought that more than the female characters, it was Tōru the one to be dependent on them. Actually I would argue that his entire growth depends on female characters. Midori teaches Tōru to take life more loosely, and Naoko teaches Tōru to be more thoughtful and responsible. Tōru becomes a real person and an adult by the end of the novel not only because he has experienced situations that have made him mature, but because he has had women around him who have been able to, let’s say, “educate” him. But whatever the truth may be, I am convinced of the beauty of Murakami’s opus. Will definitely read more from him. 
I once had a girl Or should I say, she once had me?
4/5

The style/content in Norwegian Wood is a slight deviation from the typical Haruki Murakami magical realism/otherworldness novel. No sheep? No shocking hidden secret world in the cave underneath a talking inanimate item? I say slight because everything else is there. The references to modern culture, especially John Lennon, The Beatles, other music artists, songs, etcetera. The allusion, both literally and figuratively, to dreams. The frequent references to sophisticated literature, which I am sure are a direct reflection of the author's own respectable library. The sometimes seemingly intense sexual situations with intimate, palpable detail. His ability to literally create characters readers feel like they really know. His impressive insight into emotions, relationships, psychological flaws, and complex defense mechanisms. His tendencies to use locations as characters. His use of his home country of Japan as the magnificent backdrop for his novels. Norwegian Wood, at least in Japan, is "classic" Murakami. It is the one that upgraded his status from a notable writer to a bestselling, lauded one. I am not sure how other readers see this, but I am confident Norwegian Wood is the most genre fitting of his novels; a contemporary love story. There is no magical realism, and aside from the sexuality and some detailed dreams, a rather straightforward telling, albeit a masterful, eloquent one. I have to admit that it is because of this very fact that it is one of my favorites, the others I like the most, After Dark & Sputnik Sweetheart, being similarly on the less inexplicable side of his work. Likewise, I found myself mostly disliking his most ostentatious character, Midori. I disliked her overt sexuality, comments, and tendency to act in ways that were, in my opinion, not exactly seeking attention, but still fake in a way. She did not make me uncomfortable, but definitely more grandiose than necessary. Kizuki we are never really able to meet, but I found the way he abandoned both Naoko and Toru to be rather cold. True, suicide is selfish, but more than that, some more closure for his girlfriend and best friend would have been nice. Nagasawa was... interesting. The womanizing; his treatment and/or gestures toward Hatsumi, his girlfriend, nonchalance of said treatment, general aloofness regarding life and everyone around him really had me questioning why someone as loyal, caring, conscientious, and generous as Toru would be friends with him. More details on precisely why Naoko's problems were "a lot worse than you think/it has far deeper roots". Yes, readers were given other details regarding her sister, but that does not really explain everything. Then again, maybe there is none. There were a few things Naoko did that I similarly did not appreciate, such as the way she would selfishly make Toru wait. Reiko, my second favorite after Toru, even had to, quite guiltily, write on her behalf to this man whom has treated her with nothing but tenderness and generosity and is waiting for her while she is leaving him in the dark regarding many things. Speaking of which, as this novel taking place in the 1960s, I feel that communication would have been far better than how it is portrayed? The story, at least various scenarios, would have had far different outcomes with something more reliable, more expeditious, than regular mail. Toru seems to have spent at least a quarter of the novel waiting. Waiting for Naoko to write back. Waiting for a letter from Midori. Waiting for communication via Reiko. I cannot understand why telephones were only mentioned sparingly. The hero of our story, Toru, is definitely flawed, even though he would say otherwise. But he is beautifully flawed, and that is what I love about him. He in sincere in everything he does and always tries to be the best person he can. A most admirable trait, indeed. The most important thing a person can have is character, and Toru certainly has it. I empathized with him throughout the novel, even when he was not necessarily doing the best things. This is the magic of a great writer. Aside from death, a panoply of difficult topics are addressed by Murakami, all with aptitude, eloquence, grace, and precision. As for the ending, I honestly loved how it wrapped everything up nicely, but far from easily. Like real life, not everything ends the way we want and/or expect. Life is not like a fairy tale; it is far more complex. "Death is not the opposite of life, but an innate part of life". This is what Toru says he has learned after Kizuki's suicide. I find it rather profound.

Suffice it to say, this book has consumed me over the past five days, enveloping me with feelings of nostalgia, humour, darkness, sadness, the sense of something being both lost and found and finally bittersweet loneliness and isolation. This has taught me that sometimes, periods of intense isolation are needed and it's ok to admit you are weak and need recuperation and time to discover and find yourself. Every spare moment I've had in the past few days - which have been difficult days, in which I've relished the comfort of this book, despite its extremely dark undertones - I've reached for this book as my companion amid my own loneliness and jumbled thoughts. The characters felt so real, and at times I felt I was living in Toru's head. I like how there were elements of all the character's behaviour of which I virulently disapproved of and disliked (they weren't unrealistic portrayals of people but instead three-dimensional, imperfect and flawed portraits), but in each character's I found a small piece of myself, who I am, who I'd like to be, or who I have been, or else a small piece of something I will keep in mind as I go about this world. I loved Midori, and her light moments brought relief and freshness to the wintry world of Toru's struggles and the mental struggles of those around him. Mental illness and the passages exploring the sanatorium were dealt with particularly effectively, not only giving me new insight but also helping me to understand my own self, position in this world, and helping me, oddly enough, to feel less alone, even though so much loneliness was explored in this book. The ending of this novel has left me with an ache, and like Naoko, I'm almost unable to express lucidly the various emotions I am feeling. I found an innate sadness draws the novel to a close, but there is also a sense of resilience and acceptance and spiritual growth being possible. I suppose I'm a pessimist at heart, but I'm ok with the message that is conveyed, that this is an imperfect world, and some of us merely are unable to cope with its chaos. Having to leave the world of the novel on the final page leaves me with a feeling like grief. But where I feel I have lost something special in having no more of Toru's story to read, I have also gained so much more - I have found a novel that explores some of the emotions I feel, some possible ways to deal with these emotions, and I know there are passages I will return to for solace time and again (particularly passages with Reiko and her advice to Toru). Norwegian Wood, and its protagonist Toru Watanabe, and in fact, elements of all the characters in the book, have resonated with me deeply and powerfully. I'm facing a situation in my life, and this book has given me fresh, raw insight into this situation, a chink of understanding, and means with which to arm myself and continue on living, as in the end, Toru must do, despite the pain and death that surrounds him and lives immutably within humanity. This is not a very coherent review, and I may re-write some of it, once I've had time to fully comprehend my feelings and get over the loss I feel at having finished, but I feel this is accurate proof of how this novel has really made me FEEL something - a mix of emotions I can't quite explain - and though it has hurt me as it hits close to home, I am thankful for having read it, if that makes any sense at all.

The narrator is a bit of a loner, who philosophises on life, death and love and during our time with him meets an array of odd characters. It’s a familiar tale in the fictional world of Murakami.Toru is aboard a plane when he hears ‘Norwegian Wood’ by The Beatles, which stirs up memories of his 19 year old self when he was a student at University and involved with two girls at different ends of the personality spectrum. There is Naoko, who has been slowly losing her mind since the suicide of her long term boyfriend, who also happened to be Toru’s best friend. She is finding life a depressing affair and spends the majority of the book in an institution. Her complete opposite is Midori, who is overly enthusiastic about everything bordering on maniacal. Toru meets her whilst out on his own and the two strike up a bizarre friendship.Unlike other books I’ve read by Marakami, Norwegian Wood is straight forward fiction with no elements of fantasy or the supernatural. Kafka on the Shore and Killing Commendator were marred by weirdness so a normal ‘slice of life’ story was a blessed relief. The main plot is the love triangle between Toru, Naoko and Midori but it is somewhat unconventional. Toru is unable to see Naoko because she had herself committed and Midori’s appearances are sparse depending on her mood, which means Toru spends a lot of time on his own, reflecting on the suicide of his friend, life and death in general and any other subject that causes sadness.There were times when i felt i could read 100 plus pages in one sitting, which reflects how good Murakami can be. His writing is so interesting and philosophical and unlike any author I’ve read but what let this novel down was the sheer amount of graphic sex. Even though Toru is a bit of a downbeat loner he’s certainly a hit with the ladies and barely has time to put his manhood away before someone else is stroking it. I’ve come to expect sex in Murakami’s books but some of the scenes in Norwegian Wood are borderline ridiculous and after a while i was sick of reading about ‘semen’, ‘breasts’ and how ‘wet she was’. It become a bore.Norwegian Wood is a good book but due to the sex, most of it unnecessary, i can’t go above 3 stars.
“Writing from memory like this, i often feel a pang of dread. What if I’ve forgotten the most important thing? What if somewhere inside me there is a dark limbo where all the truly important memories are heaped and slowly turning into mud…“

Norwegian Wood by Haruki MurakamiShe strummed the guitar in search of the opening chord of Scarborough Fair. This was apparently her first attempt at the song but after a few false starts she got to go where she could play it through without hesitating. Norwegian Wood follows the protagonist, Toru, as he comes of age in Tokyo in the late 1960’s. The period covers several years of high school and early university. The story focuses on his romantic relationships and to a lesser extent on his dormitory roommates. It is beautifully written with a strong realistic and historical grounding. This is the first generation coming of age who were born after the war.Now I’m certainly no sage when it comes to guessing plots so it was a little disappointing when I predicted how Toru’s three relationships with Naoko, Midori, and Reiko would unfold. Foreshadowing is not always a bad thing but the plot here seemed especially straightforward. As far as minor points, Murakami’s protagonist could have spent a few more chapters in the present. How had his life turned out etc? In this regard I enjoyed the circa 1987 glimpses as he ponders his past life. In comparison to other works, I liked Murakami’s Kafka By the Shore a little more as it felt more mysterious. The quality of writing though is similar and excellent in both books.4 stars. Murakami can really turn a phrase. There were many poignant discussions between Toru and his romantic interests. And there was a lot of focus on sex.

È impossibile che qualcuno possa sempreproteggere un altro, in eterno.Recensire questo romanzo, così come tutte le opere di questo straordinario narratore giapponese, è davvero difficile per la vastità delle tematiche che affronta e per l'approfondimento psicologico dei personaggi che di volta in volta, nelle sue storie (quasi sempre lunghissime) ci pennella. Allo stesso tempo staccarsi dai suoi romanzi è impossibile, ti porta a finirli entro tre/quattro giorni (dipende quanto tempo abbiamo a disposizione e, credetemi, potreste passare tante notti insonni pur di portarlo a termine).Di sicuro, è un romanzo che coinvolge, appassiona e commuove. Il protagonista, Toru Watanabe, ricorda gli anni dell'adolescenza e dell'università. Una fase di passaggio ricca di felicità e tristezza: l'estrema umanità nella solitudine di quel che resta, il primo vero e incredibile amore, il senso dell'amicizia, la perdita, la crescita e la scelta, la vita che cerca il modo di fiorire e andare avanti, la morte che, senza alcuna spiegazione o perchè, la rende bella così com'è. Il delicatissimo passaggio dall'adolescenza alla vita adulta, raccontato attraverso lo schermo della malinconia, la forza delle emozioni e della memoria che cerca di conservare, a tutti i costi, quello che è irrimediabilmente perduto.

So... this book was a struggle...I am absolutely gutted by the fact that I didn't love Norwegian Wood! I have been looking forward to reading Murakami for so long, and based of everything I've heard about his work I was sure it was going to be love at first page. But it wasn't. Not even close. I've actually considered not finishing it a few times.I did love Murakami's writing style, and this experience is not going to stop me from reading at least 2 of his other novels. I also think there IS a good story somewhere in this book, at least there were parts that I found interesting and compelling, but the majority of this was just not for me. I don't enjoy romance as a genre (or frequent graphic descriptions of sex), but I could get behind it if I'm really interested in the characters, which wasn't the case here. If I had to pick a character I actually came close to liking it would have to be Reiko.Look, I know I sound like a prude right now, which I'm not, but I really have no interest in reading about a 19-going-on-20-year-old's cumming of age (this is not a typo). I can understand why people love this book, I'm just not one of them.

اصلا کتاب مناسبی برای خوندن توی هفته ی قبل از پریود نیست همینجوری ادم حس مرگ و خودکشی داره توی این هفته ها این کتابم بهش دامن میزنه ولی در کل من این ژاپنیا رو دوسدارم انیمه های افسردشونو دوسدارم و این کتابای دلگیرو داغونو کلا موراکامیو دوسندارم اخساس میکنم خیلی مرخرف زیاد میگه اینکه همش تو کتابا از موسیقی میکه و اینو بهرخ میکشه که خیلی موسیقی سرش میشه حال بهم زنه درضمن فک نکنم ژاپنیا واقعا اینقد زیاد درگیر موسیقیای غربی باشن . گوش میدن مث خود ما و مثل هر شرقیه دیگه ای اما میگم که موراکامی مزخرف زیاد میگه اول و اخر کتابو نتونستم بفهمم یا من گیج بودم یا مبههم نوشته بودش خلاصه اگه کسی این رو میبینه و دوسدارم از سیاهی و ظلمت نفهمیم دربیام

War das wirklich mal meine liebste Geschichte von Murakami? Der Re-Read hat ein schlimmes Gefühl der Ernüchterung hinterlassen.Schreibstil eher banal und die ernste Geschichte hinter Naokos Art geht völlig unter neben den 682947473 Sexszenen, vulgären Gesprächen über Sex und den merkwürdigen Figuren, die scheinbar an nichts anderes denken können. Ich hatte irgendwann vor jeder Szene Angst, in der Toru einer Frau begegnet, in 99% der Fälle lief es dann auch wieder auf eine weitere belanglose Sexszene hinaus. Bin offiziell genervt von dieser Seite Murakamis. Leider. 😥

What I learned from Naoko’s death was this: no truth can cure the sorrow we feel from losing a loved one. No truth, no sincerity, no strength, no kindness can cure that sorrow. All we can do is see it through to the end and learn something from it, but what we learn will be no help in facing the next sorrow that comes to us without warning. Hearing the waves at night, listening to the sound of the wind, day after day I focused on these thoughts of mine.

Απο τα βιβλία που νιώθεις μια θλίψη οταν τελειώνει, γιατί συνειδητοποιείς ότι "δεν θα κάνετε αλλο παρέα". Αυτή ακριβώς ήταν η αίσθηση όσες μέρες το διάβαζα:παρέα. Σίγουρα εχεις κατι κοινό με τους χαρακτηρες. Πρώτη επαφή με τον Μουρακάμι και σίγουρα οχι η τελευταία.
me he quedado en shock con el final 🫠

Norwegian Wood is my first Murakami Novel, his unique writing style and unimaginable story telling skills put me under a spell, of which the enchantment was broken over the last page turned. Set in the years 1968 to 1970, the theme of alienation and sense of loss is prominent in this novel, but Murakami's true achievement lies in the vision and humour he brings to even the most despairing moments of his story. When 30-something the main protagonist in the story, Toru Watanabe, hears a fragment of the popular Beatles track after a long airplane flight, his memories are returned to his days as a young student and his love affair with the beautiful but damaged Naoko. Norwegian Wood can only offer a path through the frozen woods, it really can't make us follow that path. As a conclusion, I am not sure whether Toru accepts love or carries on in grief, but if you find yourself wandering among the trees this winter, figuring out what life is all about, the feeling of loss for a loved one or just pure nostalgia, I can recommend Norwegian Wood as a guidebook.
Quotes from this book that will stay with me forever !
"But who can say what's best? That's why you need to grab whatever chance you have of happiness where you find it, and not worry about other people too much. My experience tells me that we get no more than two or three such chances in a life time, and if we let them go, we regret it for the rest of our lives.""If you only read the books that everyone else is reading, you can only think what everyone else is thinking."“I was always hungry for love. Just once, I wanted to know what it was like to get my fill of it -- to be fed so much love I couldn't take any more. Just once. ”“ Letters are just pieces of paper,” I said. “Burn them, and what stays in your heart will stay; keep them, and what vanishes will vanish.”

Impregnada de un halo de nostalgia y melancolía, Tokio Blues, nos narra una historia donde la vida y la muerte se entrelazan en la cotidianidad de nuestros personajes. Murakami nos muestra seres perdidos en sí mismo, en sus recuerdos, incapaces de amar y de ser felices; temorosos a su destino y a una vida desoladora y sin sentido. La novela es un relato de amor manchada por la pérdida, por las despedidas y la tristeza de cada uno de los personajes.La novela nos muestra los recuerdos de juventud de Watanabe. En ella recuerda a la novia de su amigo fallecido Kizuki, llamada Naoko, que años después de este evento que marcó a ambos termina por unirlos de manera sentimental. Escrita en primera persona, el autor tiene una construcción fenomenal de los personajes que brillan con luz propia y nos permite empatizar con sus nostálgicas vidas, percibir sus miedos y alegrarnos con los destellos de felicidad que contienen sus historias.Haruki Murakami, el eterno candidato al Nobel de literatura, siempre llamó mi atención y siendo esta la primera vez que logro leer algo de su narrativa. Aunque esta novela sea contada de manera más sencilla y sincera, he podido percibir su visión occidentalizada de su original estilo. Esta lectura es pausada y se medita en diversos temas a manera de reflexión. Creo firmemente que la novela logra ser excelente más por sus personajes femeninos que por la misma trama argumental. Midori y Reiko son dos ejemplos de ello.🌟🌟🌟🌟

I understand the fuzz around this book, certainly a good novel with that typical Japanese -don't expect a happy ending- atmosphere. However, I have mixed feelings about it: At first I liked it, then it became tedious for me, like I was not going anywhere. After a while it seemed absurd as it improved.Then it was shit, and then at the middle end I took hold of the question and I started to like it again, except for the last sex scene, I don't know what it comes to, it was SUPER RIDICULOUS!!.The unnecessary descriptions of the woman's body made me uncomfortable, not to mention the various sexual episodes that seemed exaggerated, mechanical and at times unrelated.Reflections on mental health are the most interesting to me. Talking about these issues through the protagonists, teenagers transitioning to adults, was without a doubt what caught me the most about Norwegian Wood. However, I believe that something was missing to make this book sensational.

4,5/5Νεορομαντικό ανάγνωσμα, πολύ καλογραμμένο, δυνατό, μια πλημμύρα συναισθηματων στην Ιαπωνία του τέλους του '60 και των αρχών του '70. Εσωστρεφες και μελαγχολικό, μας συστήνει με μια διαφορετική κουλτούρα (sixties χωρίς την παραμικρή νύξη για ναρκωτικά ή παραισθησιογόνα) σε μια εποχή μεγάλων αλλαγών. Όμως τα ανθρώπινα συναισθήματα, παντού σχεδόν είναι τα ίδια. Έρωτας, φιλία, αγάπη, μελαγχολία, αλκοόλ, σεξ, κατάθλιψη, ό,τι χρειάζεται ένα -έστω και χωρις ιδιαίτερη πλοκή- μυθιστόρημα για να αρέσει στον πολύ κόσμο, καταφέρνοντας ωστόσο να ξεχωρίσει ποιοτικά από τον σωρό του είδους. Πρώτη μου επαφή με τον Μουρακαμι, απολογισμός θετικότατος.

هیچ چیز مثل یک کتاب خوب نمیتونه حال آدمو خوب کنههیچ لذتی (به جرات) بالاتر از خواندن کتابِ خوب نیستبا اینکه نقص هایی در ترجمه ی این نسخه ای که خواندم وجود داشت، اما چقدر، چقدر، چقدر از خواندن این کتاب لذت بردمالان و بعد از خواندن جنگل نروژی، هاروکی موراکامی هم در کنار جی دی سلینجر برای من یک روانشناسه که قلم به دست میگیرهداستان کتاب شاید یک زندگی معمولی باشه که بخشِ مرگ در اون پررنگ شده، اما به قدری روان و سیال نگارش شده که شناو��م کرد

Ovde ima ne jedna, nego čak DVE manic pixie dream girls sa različitim dijagnozama i čiji je jedini razlog postojanja da vode mlađanog protagonistu kroz seksualno-egzistencijalnu krizu, a ima i nešto što bi moglo biti svrstano jedino pod koncept manic pixie dream babe (postarije gospođe, koja ima svega trideset devet godina, a opet se njene bore, iskustvo i pripovedanje toliko potenciraju kao da ima bar sedamdeset).

Un bellissimo libro, affronta in modo delicato temi abbastanza complessi. Primo libro di Murakami che leggo, mi piace il suo modo di raccontare e sicuramente proverò a leggere altro di suo..“Sono uno di quelli che per capire le cose ha assolutamente bisogno di scriverle.”
Lectura diferente a lo que suelo leer, pero es entretenida, aunque el ritmo sea un poco lento. 7/10
One of my new favourites! ✨

۱۲ نیمه‌شب ۳۰ بهمن: دلم میخواد همین الان برم بیرون و تا صبح قدم بزنم و به خودم و دنیای اطرافم فکر کنم و چوب نروژی رو گوش بدم.۱۲ ظهر ۳۰ بهمن: از وقتی تموم شده دارم بهش فکر میکنم. قبل از خواب بهش فکر کردم. وقتی تو ماشین که بودم به سمت بیمارستان بهش فکر کردم. توی کلاس و بخش‌ بهش فکر کردم و کم و بیش چیزایی که به ذهنم میومد رو یادداشت کردم.I once had a girl;Or should I say she once had me!موراکامی این کتاب رو با الهام از اولین جملات آهنگ چوب نروژی بیتلز نوشته.شخصیت اصلی داستان، تورو واتانابه، یه پسر معمولی، تودل‌برو، عاقل نسبت به سنش و منطقیه. و خب تو شرایط مضخرفی گیر کرده! دوست صمیمی‌ش، کیزوکی، خودکشی کرده و تورو برای فاصله گرفتن از این اتفاق به توکیو میاد. در عین حال دوست‌دختر کیزوکی، ناوکو، هم به همین دلیل به توکیو اومده.برحسب اتفاق تورو با ناوکو ملاقات میکنه و بعد از چند روز وقت گذروندن باهاش، هدف جدیدش رو پیدا میکنه. اینکه ناوکو رو از این چاه تاریک و عمیقی که توش گیر افتاده نجات بده.تورو ناوکو رو دوست داره اما ناوکو ناامید از همه‌چی، قادر به دوست داشتن دیگری نیست. به قدری در تاریکی و غم فرورفته که هیچ‌کس نمیتونه او رو از این حالت بیرون بیاره.از طرف دیگر تورو با میدوری آشنا میشه. دختری سر‌زنده، شاد، پر از امید به زندگی. نقطه‌ی مقابل ناوکو. میدوری هم با مشکلاتی مشابه مواجه میشه. او تورو دوست داره اما تمام فکر و ذکر تورو معطوف به ناوکوهه.تورو همون تصمیمی رو میگیره که اگه ما به جای او بودیم هم همون تصمیم رو میگرفتیم. او همچنان به هدف اصلیش فکر میکنه. هر روز به فکر ناوکوست و براش نامه مینویسه و ناوکو تمام نامه‌هاش رو بدون پاسخ میذاره. در حالی که هیچ خبری از میدوری نمیگیره. در کنار تمام توصیفاتی که موراکامی از مرگ، عشق، دوستی و... داره، ما رو در جریان روال عادی زندگی تورو قرار میده. باهاش سر کلاس‌های دانشگاه‌ش میریم. با دوستش شب‌ها به بار میریم و... . همین باعث میشه که بیشتر با تورو اخت بگیریم.تورو فکر میکنه انسانی معمولی‌ایه؛ بدون هیچ ویژگی خاص. قدر خودش رو نمیدونه. همیشه خودش رو در موقعیتی پیدا میکنه که نفر سوم روابطه‌. رابطه‌ی کیزوکی و ناوکو، هاتسومی و ناگاساوا و... . تورو خودش رو با ادمای اطرافش تعریف میکنه.تورو از زندگی یک چیز رو میخواست. نجات ناوکو از چاه عمیق و تاریکی که توش گیر افتاده. به همین دلیل با مرگ ناوکو هیچ هدفی براش باقی نمیمونه. خودش رو گم میکنه.وقتی به خودش میاد میبینه که وسط یه خیابون ایستاده و مردم از کنارش میگذرن.الان نوبت توروست که انتخاب کنه که برای خودش زندگی کنه و خودش رو با روابطش با دیگران تعریف نکنه.و این بنظرم بهترین پایان برای این سفر دردناک و طاقت‌فرساست.پ.ن: هر کدوم از ما بعد از خوندن چوب نروژی احساس میکنیم بخشی از داستان بخشی از زندگی خودمونه که قبلا تجربه کردیم. فکر میکنم تجارب این‌چنینی همون چیزین که مارو از مرز بین جوانی و بزرگسالی رد میکنند.سال گذشته، توی ۲۱ سالگی تجربه‌ای مشابه با تورو داشتم. من هم خودم رو با روابطم با دیگران تعریف میکردم. حواسم به خودم نبود و وقتی به خودم اومدم دیدم هنوز سر جای اولم ایستادم و ادما، بی‌اهمیت از کنارم میگذرن. منم مثل تورو باید از ناوکوی خودم دل میکندم و بالاخره باور میکردم که او نمیتونه عشقی که من میخوام ازش رو بهم بده.

Norwegian Wood é um romance do escritor japonês Haruki Murakami publicado em 1987. A temática da obra aborda o fim dos anos 60, onde por todo o mundo se registavam grandes transformações sociais e políticos. Murakami descreve as vivências dos jovens universitários, a saída da adolescência e a transição para o estado adulto. O cessante questionamento sobre idealismo e o existencialismo, a compreensão do eu e do mundo ao redor, as emoções que unem e afastam pessoas, o papel que cada um assume perante a sociedade, o que esperam os outros de nós, e o que nós queremos dar/ser para os outros, Murakami retrata os anos loucos da década de 60, a revolução sexual e os protestos juvenis contra a ameaça de endurecimento dos governos. A musica dos Beatles fazia furor e era transmitida pelo mundo inteiro. Neste clima “the sixties” que o autor cria a história de (Toru, Kizuki e Nagasawa) vs (Naoko, Midori e Reiko).No campo feminino, três mulheres, cada uma representa um molde diferente, um olhar diferente sobre a personalidade feminina. Todas amam Toru e todas são amadas por ele, cada uma à sua maneira. A sensível, introvertida e suicida, que o deixa abeira de um ataque de nervos sem saber como agir. A desmiolada, ninfomaníaca que o provoca constantemente, por um lado o excita, por outro o assusta, ficando ele sem saber como agir. Por fim a mulher madura, antropofóbica e com serias dúvidas quanto à sua sexualidade, por quem Toru sente uma empatia enorme, um elo entre ele as suas duas grandes paixões. No campo masculino: Rapaz rico, só e incompreendido, tem tudo, mas no campo sócio-afetivo, tem dificuldades em dar/receber amor, suicida-se. O arrogante, egoísta que apenas procura dar-se bem na vida, entra na vida política. O rapaz sensível, em busca da compreensão de si mesmo e do mundo que o rodeia, odeia desapontar os outros, mas acaba sempre por fazê-lo, está sempre a pedir desculpa, quando está com uma, só pensa na outra.Gostei da história, mas não gostei da tradução, um português corriqueiro, boçal. As traduções perdem muito do seu verdadeiro contexto quando os tradutores não conhecem culturalmente e historicamente os países cuja língua estão a traduzir. Creio que esta obra de Murakami ficou desfavorecida por este facto. Deixo o link para alguém que tenha interesse em ver filme, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dIMZG..., apesar de não ser nada mau, o livro supera o filme.Deixo o link para o vídeo da música dos Beatles Norwegian Wood https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rl2xQ...PoemaI once had a girlOr should I say she once had meShe showed me her roomIsn't it good Norwegian wood?She asked me to stayAnd she told me to sit anywhereSo I looked aroundAnd I noticed there wasn't a chairI sat on a rug biding my timeDrinking her wineWe talked until two and then she said"It's time for bed"She told me she workedIn the morning and started to laughI told her I didn'tAnd crawled off to sleep in the bathAnd when I awoke I was aloneThis bird had flownSo I lit a fireIsn't it good Norwegian wood?

Music: Cornershop - "Norwegian Wood" (in my opinion the best cover of the song)Through a song, Toru Watanabe is transported back to late 1960s Tokyo, where he is a college student devoted to the girlfriend of his late schoolmate Kazuki, Naoko. As she gradually starts to withdraw from the world, he has to face his own growing up and a new love, a modern girl named Midori.There are some elements in the story that occur in other Murakami books (a well, cats, spaghetti, mysterious women). Besides the two women above, there is also Naoko's sanitorium friend, a slightly older woman named Rieko, who is important to the story. Two men also are important in their own way - Toru's roommate nicknamed Storm Trooper (neatfreak, geography-obsessed), and Nagasawa, honest but arrogant womanizer who is an odd friend to have but somehow fits the story.Naoko's declining mental health drives Toru into his own mental crisis, but it helps him to grow up more, and realise things. Rieko also seems to come out of her own locked state as a result of being Naoko's roommate (her own story of why she's there is quite rough, and one of the hardest things to read in this book). It's tough to read about how helpless Toru is, how he can't really help Naoko. Still, he is sometimes quite oblivious to some clues and blurts out things that are not helpful. His own sexual adventures probably are quite normal for a guy of his age, but I feel the book brings it out perhaps a bit too much for my liking.But there's much to like: the nature, the foods that are eaten, the cat named Seagull, the books Toru reads, and how Toru changes also in positive manner, taking more responsibility of his own life, even if he can't always help others. Midori is perhaps the least shown woman in this story, but she's seen from Toru's POV. Her own struggles and loneliness are hidden a lot from sight; finally towards the end Toru realises how much he loves her and tries to mend his way back into it - still, the end of the story leaves things a little open (but as the story is told from a point in the future, things have moved on from the end point in the past where the book ends - so although we don't know how the relationship with Midori turned out, if it's still on or not, I feel like choosing the optimistic choice).So: this book is a bit different from the usual Murakami book style; it being a good point to start reading Murakami may be right or not. If the sexual things in the book had been lesser or more vague (especially the one that sent Rieko to the sanitorium, and the only time Toru and Naoko had sex) I would've probably thought of this as a four-star book. If and when I reread this, there will be some places where I skip a bit, but I do think this book was worth reading, even if just once. It does make you think about mental health, life and death, maturing, and the choices one makes, for some time after reading it. Very worthy reading experience.

نوشتن دربارش سخته:)موقع خوندنش قطعا پنج ستاره بود، یعنی برای من یه تجربه‌ی پنج ستاره بود، توصیف‌های واضح، روشن و به‌اندازه، شخصیت‌های عالی پرداخته شده و احساسات ظریف و عمیق و روابط پیچیده و غیرآبکی.خیلی آروم خوندمش و تقریبا به جز شروعش که یکم کند بود بقیه‌ش تمام مدت توجهم رو کامل جلب کرده بود (perfect escapism)‌. کل کتاب پره از جملاتی که خط کشیدم و هایلایت کردم، چون واقعا هنرمندانه نوشته شده بودن، نه صرفا پیچیده ولی زیبا.اگر بخوایم بگیم کتاب درباره چیه، درباره‌ی از دست دادن آدم‌هایی که برامون خیلی عزیزن، کنار اومدن یا نیومدن با اندوهش و بزرگ شدن... داستان درباره‌ی کیه؟ درباره‌ی یه پسریه در انتهای نوجوانی که خارج از شهر خودش زندگی میکنه و با دختر(ها)یی که وضعیت روانی پیچیده‌ای دارن می‌خوابه... (این میتونه توصیف تقریبا همه‌ی کتابای موراکامی باشه:دی- حداقل اونهایی که من خوندم).با این کتاب هم همون مشکلی رو داشتم که با "کافکا در کرانه" داشتم؛ شخصیت‌های زن داستان فقط زیبان، فقط عجیب و زیبا. چیزی مستقل از خودشون ندارن، باورپذیر نیستن، فقط یه گوشه وایمیستن تا پسر داستان یکاری "باهاشون" بکنه، انگار خارج از نقششون توی زندگی اون پسر وجود ندارن. تازه همه‌ی شخصیت‌های مونث توی این کتاب با شخصیت پسر اصلی میخوابن، زیبا نیست؟!-درباره‌ی ترجمه: من ترجمه رو نه خوندم نه دیدم، فارغ از اینکه مترجم کارش رو خوب انجام داده باشه یا نه، قسمت‌های خیلی زیادی از کتاب هستن که مطمئنا سانسور و حذف میشن که این به داستان و فضاش خیلی آسیب میزنه، تازه قابل حدس هم نیستن که بگی خب اینجا که معلومه اینا چیکار میکنن، اینجوریه که یهو دوتا آدم خیلی دور از ذهن میرن پشت بوته ها! بنابراین یا کلا زبان اصلی بخونید یا حداقل پی‌دی‌اف کنارتون باشه تطابق بدید.-درباره‌ی فیلم: فیلمش به تنهایی، اگر از وجود کتاب خبر نداشته باشیم فیلم خوبیه، مخصوصا از نظر زیبایی بصری. ولی در مقایسه با داستان اصلا حرفی برای گفتن نداره، کل این تجربه‌ی انسانی پیچیده رو تبدیل کرده به یه رومنس ساده. چون بیشتر قسمت های قشنگ کتاب گفتگوی درونی شخصیت‌هاست که توی فیلم نمیشه نشونش داد.همین دیگه، ممنونم که خوندید:)

Sembra una storia apparentemente semplice quella che Murakami - con Norwegian Wood - vuole raccontarci, eppure trasuda esistenzialismo da tutti i pori. Sviscera una fase importante della crescita umana: l’età adolescenziale, fatta di turbamenti e incertezze ma soprattutto di fragilità emotive.Servendosi di una prosa asciutta e coinvolgente, lontana dai suoi canoni prettamente onirici, l’autore ci descrive una visione disincantata della realtà, mette a nudo i sentimenti dando vita ad un lungo e malinconico flashback che lo avvicina di molto al romanzo di formazione.Il titolo si ricollega alla celeberrima canzone dei Beatles e ci dà un chiaro indizio su uno dei temi che verranno affrontati: l’amore. Un altro leitmotiv che riecheggerà per tutto il romanzo è l’ineluttabilità della morte intrinsecamente associata alla vita, una sorta di indissolubile yin e yang. Watanabe, il protagonista, è un ragazzo che per la sua giovane età si ritrova a subire esperienze molto forti, primo fra tutti il suicidio del suo migliore amico appena diciassettenne. E anche i personaggi che gli girano intorno non sono da meno, si tratta di vite costellate da momenti bui.“Si cresce e si cambia”, mi ripete spesso mia madre e questo romanzo le dà ragione. L’ingresso nell’età adulta implica un ridimensionamento di sogni e aspettative, non possiamo cullarci nell’idea di restare eterni Peter Pan; prima o poi saranno le esperienze a tracciare il confine di passaggio tra uno stadio e l’altro.

2016 yılında okuduğum en saçma ve boş kitaptı.Anlatılmaya çalışılan -ve bence başarısız olan- ele avuca sığmayan anlamsız hüznü geçersek, gerisi daha anlamsız bir şekilde (olması sanki mümkünmüş gibi) cinsellikten ibaretti. Tamam tamam biliyorum, Japonlar ve bastırılmış duyguları. Lakin Japon Edebiyatı bu değil arkadaşlar, değil.Küfür gibi.Başarısız betimlemeleri, devrik cümleleri, konuyu havada bırakıp hadi sevişelim'e getirmeleri ve 350 sayfa boyunca süregelen bu saçma döngüye bakarak kendime sürekli şunu soruyorum: 5 puan verenler tam olarak neye göre verdiler?Renkler ve zevkler mi? Zevk olduğu bariz canım. Yere göğe sığdıramadığınız Murakami benim için yine sınıfta kaldı.Zamanımın israfına yanıyorum, çok yazık!

بعد ما قررت أن لا أقرا لهذا الكاتب مجددا.إلا أنني بصدفة في مدونة ذكروا أن هذه الرواية تعتبر من كلاسيكيات هذا العصر لذلك تشجعت لقراتها.ابدأ من كمية الكآبة التي إعتارتني:بطل الذي أحب و ما زال يحب "ناكوا "حبيبة صديقه المنتحر في"17" من عمره و التي ل�� تبادله الحب..مع وصف نزاعها مع مشاكلها المرضية هذا الإطار العام للرواية.مع تواجد علاقات اخرى بينه و بين صديقه "ناغسوا" و زميلته في الجامعة.الذي أساني في الرواية كمية الأفكار الانتحارية و الشخصيات التي انتحرت: 4 شخصيات و كمية المقاطع الجنسية في الرواية.صدقا لم اخرج من هذه الرواية إلا بجملة واحدها قالها صديق البطل ناغسوا:قال:اريد ان اكون جلنتلمانم معنى ذلك: قال: ان تفعل م لا تريد بل م ينتظر بك أن تفعل.je suis déçu de cet roman. Im so so disappointed.بالتونسي اني فديت منه .13 mai 2018.🌹

This book is everything that the Beatles song is. It's a longing to belong to the past, it's a longing to break away from it. It's a deep, unerring desire to seek happiness, walking through the mazes of your own memory, trying to seek it in what was and what could have been. It's also the warm winter sunshine that whispers something softly into your ear. It's poetry in motion.

"This book had me hooked after a few pages! It is a very tragic story of young love, but also holds hope, joy and plenty of humor and a terrific cast of characters. I have no doubt that this will stay with me for a long time and should it start to fade I will want/need to re-read it, highly recommended!"

Che volete che dica, questo libro è la dimostrazione che Murakami è in grado di scrivere un gran bel romanzo anche uscendo dalla sua comfort zone, impiegando un genere diverso dal suo solito. Non posso che apprezzarlo tantissimo.
"I once had a girl,or should I say,she once had me."
لعل مشاعرك الطيبة هي ما أحتاج إليه بالضبط في هذه الفترة من حياتي

"Deja de atormentarte por esto. Las cosas fluyen hacia donde tienen que fluir, y por más que te esfuerces e intentes hacerlo lo mejor posible, cuando llegue el momento de herir a alguien lo hieres"Me devoré este libro. Desde un principio la prosa sencilla pero profunda de Murakami me atrapó, la forma en que narra es como si estuvieras ahi, puedes ver cada lugar que describe, escuchar cada canción, saborear la comida, y sentir la lucha de Watanabe por encontrarle un sentido a la vida.Siempre he admirado la forma en que los japoneses ven la vida, tan distinta a los occidentales. Murakami aborda el tema del suicidio, de las enfermedades mentales, la amistad, el sexo y las relaciones familiares y amorosas de una forma que te envuelve en su relato, y, a pesar de ser una historia cruda en ciertos momentos, te hace reflexionar sobre la vida, como lo dice uno de los personajes de la historia está "Todos nosotros somos seres imperfectos que vivimos en un mundo imperfecto. Y no debemos vivir de una manera tan rígida, midiendo la longitud con una regla y los ángulos con un transportador como si la vida fuera un depósito bancario."La forma en que Murakami expone el dilema del amor y qué es el amor para Watanabe es muy real, y creo que en algún momento todos podriamos sentirnos identificados con la confusión y los sentimientos encontrados que vivimos en la juventud."Ellos debían de conocer muy bien la soledad y la dulzura de la vida humana, ¿no crees?Con 'ellos' Reiko se refería, por supuesto, a John Lennon, Paul McCartney y George Harrison."**English**"Stop tormenting yourself about this. Things flow where they are meant to, and no matter how hard you try and try your best, when the time comes to hurt someone you hurt them" I devoured this book. From the beginning Murakami's simple but profound prose captivated me, the way he narrates is as if you were there, you can see each place he describes, listen to each song, taste the food, and feel Watanabe's struggle to find meaning in life. I have always admired the way in which the Japanese people see life, so different from Westerners. Murakami addresses the issue of suicide, mental illness, friendship, sex, and family and love relationships in a way that envelops you in his story, and, despite being a raw story at times, makes you reflect on life, as one of the characters in the story says, is "We are all imperfect beings living in an imperfect world. And we should not live in such a rigid way, measuring length with a ruler and angles with a transporter as if life were a bank deposit." The way in which Murakami exposes the dilemma of love and what love is for Watanabe is very real, and I think that at some point we could all feel identified with the confusion and mixed feelings that we experience in youth. "They must have known very well the loneliness and sweetness of human life, don't you think? By 'they' Reiko meant, of course, John Lennon, Paul McCartney and George Harrison."

Đọc lại nhận ra nhìu cái hơn lần đầuHay quá hay lun 😌.Update 7/3/2023.Nhớ lần đầu tiên đọc, hồi cuối năm ngoái, mình đã phát cuồng vì quyển này. Đọc cảm thấy đã tới mức mua liên tục mấy cuốn của bác Mi để đọc tiếp. Lúc đó mình ko cảm thấy Rừng Na Uy buồn, tại vì trc đó nhiều ng review làm mình expect quyển này chắc phải nói về những chuyện buồn kinh khủng lắm và nói về vấn đề gì đó to lớn lắm, mấy nhân vật trong này chắc phải già cỗi lắm 😆 ko khí trong truyện phải ảm đạm tối tăm lắm!!! Đấy ko hiểu sao mình expect quyển này ghê z nên mới chần chừ ko mún đọc..Ko ngờ đọc xong cảm thấy rất khác vs ấn tượng khi nghe review. Những nhân vật trong truyện đều là những ng còn rất trẻ và có chút j đó ngông trong tính cách. Ko hề già cỗi ảm đảm tí nào. Họ rất thẳng thắn và cá tính, kể cả Naoko lun. Nhưng mà trong lần đầu đọc mình lại ko nghĩ nhiều tới vấn đề của Naoko, ko suy nghĩ nhiều tới ý nghĩa những lời cô nói. Mình hoàn toàn bị lôi cuốn bởi Midori, vì cổ tỏa sáng và đặc biệt quá 😆 từng câu nói, từng hành động, kiểu tóc, cách ăn mặc đều thú vị. Chắc ko ai đọc mà có thể cưỡng lại ko thích Midori dc. Điều ấn tượng nhất ở Midori có lẽ là sự trung thực 🤣 cái j cũng nói toẹt ra. Mà thiệt ra trong truyện này mấy bạn trẻ ai cũng đơn giản và thẳng thắn như vậy, ko có ai màu mè. Mình cứ đọc đi đọc lại mấy đoạn Toru ở bên cạnh Midori mãi 😍 dễ thương hài hước j đâu. So sánh vs 1 Naoko trầm buồn và bất ổn như thế, Midori càng nổi bật. Chắc đó cũng là lý do mà mới đầu mình thấy quyển này hơi hơi buồn ở 1 vài đoạn nhất định thôi chứ ko phải đau khổ j lắm, tại mình quá bị lôi cuốn bởi năng lượng của Midori, còn Naoko, với mình thì luôn nhạt nhòa như vốn ko còn thuộc về thế giới này nữa..Lần này đọc lại mình thấy nghĩ như z là bất công cho Naoko. Ngay từ đầu đoạn Toru đang ngồi trên máy bay nghe nhạc r nhớ lại cảnh đi dạo cùng Naoko và nói chuyện về cái giếng, mình đã bắt đầu chú ý nhiều hơn tới những lời mà Naoko nói, mình thấy từng chữ đều có ý nghĩa và đau lòng kinh khủng. Cách Naoko tả cái giếng, rơi xuống chỗ tăm tối đó sẽ ko chết hẳn mà chết dần chết mòn, r ánh mắt Naoko như muốn tìm kiếm 1 cái j đó, như cố diễn đạt 1 cái j đó cho Toru hiểu (nhưng mà ổng kbh hiểu dc), r có lúc Naoko ko thể diễn đạt dc ý mà cổ mún nói, ko thể viết thư dc cho Toru mặc dù cổ rất muốn, mình hiểu cảm giác rối loạn đó. R thêm Keiko nữa, cả Naoko và Keiko đều cho rằng bản thân mình ko nên dính vào cuộc đời của ng khác vì bik bản thân mình sẽ kéo người kia xuống, nhưng cả 2 đều cần người khác để mà sống, như việc họ trông chờ những bức thư của Toru :(((( Càng nghĩ mình càng thấy Naoko thật ra cực kì mạnh mẽ và cũng trung thực ko thua gì Midori. Cổ cũng đâu có buông xuôi bỏ cuộc mà cũng tìm cách chạy chữa, vô khu đó sống r lao động các thứ, thân thiết vs Keiko, r cũng mong đợi Toru đến. Naoko ko hề yếu đuối mà cổ cũng cố gắng hết sức để níu giữ sự sống đó chứ.
